title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: ReVision: Writers ReGroup — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
ReVision: Writers ReGroup 2/22/26

  
    
      
        
          $35.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, February 22, 2026; 1pm-3:30pm$35 Write your way into a productive and rewarding relationship with revision!Session Focus: Whole-body Characters We’ll explore ways to create vivid people on the page and strengthen other elements through character, including point of view, sense of place, and emotional resonance.Revision is to a first draft what marriage is to falling head-over heels. It is to free write what deep friendship is to casual meeting. Revision takes time, skill, caring, and fortitude. It asks that we be generous and also draw boundaries. It presents us with choices that challenge what we believe to be true about others and ourselves. Revision is not for the faint of heart, but for writers committed to their relationship with creative expression through all the rough patches. Revision allows writers to investigate their heart work and intentions and stay true.I’ll share a process that I call “Master Craft Juggling,” which incorporates my Nine Ways to Mastery approach for writing fiction, memoir, and nonfiction. The session includes a craft presentation, group discussion, and writing time.You will:• Gain perspectives and techniques for masterful revision• Build community with writers who may become trusted readers for your projects• Improve your writing and writing practice through revision• Move your projects toward publicationPlease bring your:• Open mind• Fiction or nonfiction free write, early draft, or manuscript in progress• Tools and materials for writing during the session• Writing and revision challenges to discuss, particularly as relate to the session focusThe workshop will be offered periodically with a particular focus each time. Check the schedule, and sign up when you’re ready to revise.About the Instructor: Christine Walker is a visual artist, author, and strategic visioning consultant. Her published books include the novel “Tap Dancing at the Bluebird,” the memoir “A Painter’s Garden: Cultivating the Creative Life,” the children’s book and songs “Wooleycat’s Musical Theater,” and books on writing craft — “A Writer’s Resolution: A Guided Journal for Realizing a Rewarding Writing Practice” and, for publication in 2027, “Our Writing Minds in Play: The Nine Ways Guide to Masterful Fiction & Memoir.” Her paintings are exhibited in galleries and corporate and private collections. She holds an MFA in Writing and Literature in Fiction from Bennington College and an MA in Creative Arts Interdisciplinary from San Francisco State University. The Bennington program promised: “Read one hundred books. Write one.” This motto inspired her to design teaching frameworks and courses—Master Craft Juggling, Nine Ways to Mastery, Read to Write Books—to help writers elevate their writing practice and readers to engage more deeply in enjoying and discussing books. Throughout her multi-faceted creative career, she’s found that resilience is key to a rewarding career in the arts. She brings that resilience to teaching revision as a writing skill, as well as a practice.

title: 11th Annual Farmers' Convergence
description:
The School of Adaptive Agriculture invites you to the 11th Annual Farmers’ Convergence on February 21, 2026, at the UC Hopland Research & Extension Center in Hopland, CA. 

This beloved farmer-to-farmer gathering is entering an exciting new chapter. After a decade of grassroots success, the Farmers’ Convergence is expanding to UC Hopland REC, marking a significant evolution that bridges lived farming experience with deep ecological practices. This partnership represents a deeper commitment to regenerative land stewardship and our local food economy. 

The event will bring together farmers, gardeners, schools and food activists, from beginners to seasoned veterans, conventional to experimental, for innovative solutions, knowledge exchange, and forward-thinking strategies. Together, we’ll explore soil regeneration, biodiversity, systems thinking, and economic sustainability while renewing our collective inspiration and momentum. It will include events the day before, and after. 

Everyone belongs in this conversation. Tickets are limited, so don’t delay. We hope you will join us as we champion collaborative progress and expanded possibility. 

Learn more: www.schoolofadaptiveagriculture.org/convergence

Lake County Restaurant Week 2026
description: Celebrate Lake County, California restaurants by experiencing delicious dishes and deals in 2026! Restaurant Week is a limited-time event where participating restaurants offer special menus designed to showcase their culinary strengths and attract new diners. These menus often feature multiple courses and highlight seasonal ingredients or signature dishes. Held in cities across the country, Restaurant Week typically takes place during slower seasons and can last anywhere from a few days to several weeks, giving people a chance to explore a variety of dining experiences and support local establishments.. With that in mind, the Lake County Chamber of Commerce and the Lake County Economic Development Corporation partnered with several local restauranteurs to create a Restaurant Week in Lake County.

title: Mushroom Foraging
description:
Wild mushroom season has arrived on the Sonoma Coast, where misty forests and coastal meadows nurture a dazzling diversity of fungi for curious foragers and culinary enthusiasts alike.

Join Ty the Fungi, a seasoned local forager with nearly 15 years of experience, and learn how to find, identify, and responsibly harvest wild mushrooms—from prized edibles to those best left untouched. Discover the principles of ethical foraging and deepen your connection to the landscape through this immersive, hands-on exploration.

Meet at The Lodge’s Fireside Lounge, and we’ll caravan together to the foraging site.

$160 per person, $100 \(ages 10-16\). Space is limited. This adventure is recommended for participants with moderate to advanced hiking experience.

title: Steeping Knowledge - Tea Demonstration
description:
Come to Sugarloaf for an interactive demonstration on tea lead by local culture bearer, TekTekh, a Native of Sonoma and Napa. We'll take a walk around Meadow and Hillside Trails, hearing about what she's learned from her elders while looking for cleavers, which TekTekh will harvest (permit-sanctioned) and process into a tea back at the picnic tables next to the White Barn.

Meet at the White Barn parking lot. Tickets are $20 for general admission, $10 for youth (12-17 year olds; all minors must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian), students, Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf or RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Wear layers, appropriate footwear for muddy and/or slippery trails, bring a small mug/cup for tea tasting, at least a quart of water, sun protection, and if desired, a snack. Heavy rain cancels. Parking fees apply.

title: Online: The Inheritance of Wholeness
description:
with Amana Brembry Johnson

There is a knowing that lives beneath thought, an ancient intelligence woven into the fabric of our being. The Buddha taught that everything needed for liberating the heart is already here, within this body. The path is not about becoming different, but remembering all that has been obscured by the habits of conditioning and forgetfulness.

By returning to the body as a living archive that has never stopped guiding us, we reconnect with the sacred inheritance of wholeness—a continuity passed down through the Buddhadharma and the unbroken line of ancestors whose memories flow within us. This daylong will include silent sitting meditation, Dharma reflections, breath awareness, and gentle interpersonal connections. During our time together we will reconnect with what is already ours, a sense of belonging, spacious presence, and the dignity of simply being alive. Open to both new and experienced practitioners.

title: Russian River Fungi Fest
location: Russian River Chamber of Commerce, 16209 First St, Guerneville, 95446
description:
The first ever Russian River Fungi Fest is a 2 day festival celebrating all things mushrooms 
Solar Punk Farms and the Russian River Chamber of Commerce are putting together a funky new festival in Guerneville. 
Tickets on sale January 5th, 2026 
The first even “Russian River Fungi Fest” is a two day celebration of the incredible mushrooms and mushroom culture of West Sonoma County! 
West Sonoma County is known for towering redwoods, tasty wine, quirky small towns, and our stunning river. But it’s also one of the world’s most amazing places for….Mushrooms! 
On February 21st and 22nd – we’re celebrating life’s most incredible kingdom with a two day festival celebrating all our fantastic fungi. A weekend of mushroomy markets, workshops, foraging expeditions, educational talks, mycelial networking and more. 
This event will be centered in Guerneville, CA – with satellite events happening all over west county. We are working on finalizing the program with all event details, and will share that at the beginning of February. 
Winter is gloomy season in the city, but its PEAK SEASON FOR MUSHROOMS which means there is no better time to eat, forage and talk about fungi!

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney’s Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Americana Afternoon - Familiar Strangers
location: The California Theatre of Santa Rosa, 528 7th Street, Santa Rosa, CA
description:
It don’t mean a thang, if it ain’t got that twang! Special guests: The Familiar Strangers.
The Familiar Strangers play an Americana grab bag of music from western swing to country, bluegrass, folk, blues and even a little bit of gypsy jazz! This acoustic trio (occasionally a quartet) is perfect for smaller venues (no drums) but they nevertheless generate a big response from audiences with their friendly banter and responsiveness to requests from audience members. This is a band with a sense of humor that can easily move between material designed to get you up on your feet dancing or tugging at your heart to buy another beer and lose your sorrows. Their musical palette runs from Bob Wills to Doc Watson to Django Reinhardt and more. The band recently celebrated their first recorded project, Masqurade 2020, which is already garnering critical success. 
Doors Open: 12:30 PM | Show Starts: 1:00 PM
Tickets $17 in advance. $25 at door

title: Cool Team Leader Half-Day Training
description:
Cool Petaluma is about to launch a new cohort of Cool Team Leaders! 

In the current day, some of our strongest resources are our communities and neighbors. What better way to kick off 2026 than by building bonds with the people around you?

The Cool Teams program brings people together to take care of each other while taking care of the planet. Neighborhood-based Cool Teams are the most popular option, but the program has expanded to include friend groups, faith-based groups, and coworkers–whoever forms your team.

Our Team Leader Training is where dedicated community members can step up and learn how to become Team Leaders. This training will show you how to gather neighbors or friends and kickstart community climate action! Including information on climate change, guides on how to host a cool event, and how to create real change, this training will give you everything you need to know so you can become a Team Leader in your own community.

Remember to bring a water bottle and a snack for the day!

Every Sunday from 1 to 3:30, local jazz bassist, music book publisher, and KRCB host Chuck Sher presents a rotating ensemble of professional, veteran jazz musicians in Putnam Plaza Park, right next to the Speakeasy. This event started in 2020 and has since become a staple for locals and visitors alike. Stop by and enjoy some of the best jazz the Bay Area has to offer!

title: Knitting Basics
description:
Ready to get cozy with some yarn? Join Becca Schillinger for a chill intro to knitting where you'll learn the basics and make a small project to take home!

Never picked up needles before? No worries! Becca will walk you through everything from casting on \(aka getting started\) to nailing the knit stitch. You'll work on a small project using the garter stitch, then learn how to cast off when you're done. She'll also demo some handy tricks like increases, decreases, and how to read patterns without your brain melting.

title: Sugarloaf New Volunteer Orientation
description:
When you join Sugarloaf's 200+ member volunteer community, you gain access to a whole new appreciation for your local State Park. Make meaningful connections with fellow volunteers, learn new skills, enjoy time outdoors in a beautiful setting, and play an integral role in keeping Sugarloaf Ridge State Park open and accessible for everyone.

 Join us at our next volunteer orientation to learn what it takes to steward a state park! We'll cover the history of Sugarloaf, how Sonoma Ecology Center operates the park, and the various volunteer opportunities available. Beyond the mandatory initial orientation, trainings and docent enrichment activities will take place periodically, depending on your interests and role. The orientation takes place at the Robert Ferguson Observatory classroom, located at Sugarloaf Ridge State Park. Bring: a notepad, pen, reusable drink container for warm beverages, and warm layers.

title: Author Event with Megan McDonald!!
description: Join us for a special event with Megan McDonald, author of Bunny and Clyde On the Lam, and Fairy Door Diaries: Eliza and the Hobgoblins. This event is free, but we appreciate your RSVP below so we can plan for your attendance. ABOUT BUNNY AND CLYDE ON THE LAM They couldn’t be outlaws when they tried, but now they’re being framed as fall guys? Judy Moody creator Megan McDonald and illustrator Scott Nash bring back the lovable pair for a comedy full of mischief, magic tricks, and misperceptions. Thornton’s shiny new coin has vanished into thin air! Did someone steal it? All eyes fall on Bunny and Clyde, two bad bunnies at the scene of the crime. But wait! They’re not bad bunnies. For one thing, Clyde is a chipmunk. For another thing, every time they’ve tried to be bad, they somehow came out looking as good as gold. Now, when they really are I-N-N-O-C-E-N-T, everyone decides they’re guilty? In a tight spot like this, there is only one thing for a declared pair of outlaws to do. “RUN!” says Bunny. “RUN!” says Clyde. They’re on the lam! Will the fugitives be able to outrun the possum posse and shake their bum rap? Buckle up for another wild and wicked ride with Bunny and Clyde! ABOUT FAIRY DOOR DIARIES: ELIZA AND THE HOBGOBLINS Eliza has a second adventure on the other side of the fairy door—and must call on her wits when a band of impish hobgoblins follows her home—in this enchanting tale by the award-winning author of the Judy Moody series. What’s that? Eliza hears faint music coming from behind the teeny-tiny fairy door she created low on the wall. So she presses her ear to the door and—shwoosh!—is whisked into the red, rocky land of hobgoblins, leaving behind the heaps of toys and books that were strewn around her room \(along with her mother’s orders to clean them up\). Luckily, Eliza discovers that the pointy-hatted hobs love to play, love a mess, and can grant wishes! But when she wishes that Hobby, Nobby, and Tobby would help her with her room, she learns that what hobgoblins actually love is playing tricks—and as they burst into her space, it’s clear that she’s fallen for their trickery. Can she outrun their mischief before they decorate all of her walls with crayon and turn her ceiling fan into a hobgoblin merry-go-round? Just maybe . . . but only if she can come up with a few tricks of her own! Megan McDonald’s follow-up to Eliza and the Flower Fairies, illustrated in glowing full color by Lenny Wen, is sure to be happily devoured by every child who fervently believes in fairies and other magical folk. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Megan McDonald is the author of the popular Judy Moody and Stink series for older readers and the Judy Moody and Friends series for beginning readers. She has also written many other chapter books and picture books for children, including two books in the Fairy Door Diaries early chapter-book series. Megan McDonald lives in California.

title: Becoming Beloved Community
description: Journey to the meaning, history, and current reality of Becoming Beloved Community, a tenet of Dr. King’s and a way of life that stresses wholeness for humanity. Jennifer Snow, scholar and author of Mission Race and Empire, will sketch the history and theology of the Becoming Beloved Community way of life, through activists, priests, and churches. Kirstyne Lange, President of the Santa Rosa/Sonoma County NAACP, will describe the present state of the Sonoma County racial justice experience. Stephen Shaver, Rector of The Church of Incarnation, will offer a pastor’s view of how a thriving church strives for Beloved Community.

title: Cameron Mackintosh & Disney’s Mary Poppins at 6th Street Playhouse
location: 6th Street Playhouse G.K. Hardt Theatre, 52 West 6th Street, Santa Rosa, CA
description:
The beloved story of Mary Poppins soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.
Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!”

title: Flavors of Film Series takes you to England with Chicken Run!
description:
The family-favorite Flavors of Film Series: Family Edition returns with a brand-new global twist! This season, we invite you to join us every fourth Sunday from February 22 through May 31 to explore different cultures and corners of the world through a curated lineup of exciting films and interactive, food-based experiences that bring each movie to life. 

Our first stop takes us to England with the classic stop-motion favorite, *Chicken Run*! Following the screening, there will be hands-on activities inspired by British flavors and culinary traditions, blending storytelling, laughter, and learning.

title: Free Concerts on the Corner Presents: The Kyle Athayde Dance Party
location: Christ Presbyterian Church in Terra Linda
description: Kyle Athayde Dance Party presents a one-of-a-kind children’s jazz concert that offers something for everyone. Built around imaginative, jazz-infused arrangements of beloved children’s songs like “If You’re Happy and You Know It,” “The Wheels on the Bus,” and “Five Speckled Frogs,” the show is a celebration of music that is fun and accessible for all audiences. Through thoughtful programming, Kyle strikes a rare balance—creating music that delights young audiences, educates newcomers to jazz, and satisfies even the most seasoned listener. Each tune turns familiar melodies into vibrant, jazz experiences that introduce kids to rhythm, improvisation, and musical storytelling. Whether you’re a toddler, a jazz-curious parent, or a lifelong music lover, this is a show where everyone walks away with joy, discovery, and a deeper appreciation for jazz.

title: My Children! My Africa! - Live Theatre
description:
Four Performances Remaining -

My Children! My Africa! is Athol Fugard’s masterpiece about South Africa circa 1985.  In the last gasp of Apartheid, violent protest and resistance on all sides is at its height. A gentle Black high school teacher in a rural township invites a White high school girl from the town nearby to form a radical, cross-racial competitive debate team with his best pupil.  The racial, economic, and identity conversation that blossoms among the three is cut off as the revolutionary wave sweeps them all away.  Your heart will ache at the beauty of the language and the storytelling from South Africa’s master-writer, Fugard. Directed by Robert Parsons.

Hope has broken loose in Athol Fugard’s My Children! My Africa!, and those eager to embrace it had best beware, hope as a dream that evolves into a nightmare reality, it is heartbreaking. — New York Times

Featuring:

Mr. M – Ansley Valentine

Thami Mbikwana – Isaac Addai

Isabel Dyson – Emma Lenza

title: Poetry, Music and Art! A Trifecta!
description: Join us for an entrancing afternoon with two esteemed poets, Donna Emerson and Gerald Fleming, with selected readings from their recent poetry collections, respectively, Daphne Lifts Up and The Bastard & The Bishop. Our audience will be swept away by musical interludes on various stringed instruments from award-winning composer and musician, Jared Emerson-Johnson. Local watercolor artist and college instructor, Barbara Marlin, creator of the Daphne Lifts Up book cover will display the original artwork and selected prints of other work at the event. Following the readings and music, a Q&A will follow, with book sales and signing in the lobby. Refreshments will be available for sale. This is free event, all donations always gratefully accepted.    Donna Emerson divides her time between Petaluma, California, and her family homestead near Ithaca, New York. Retired from teaching at Santa Rosa Jr. College and her clinical social work practice, her recent poetry publications include La Pressa, The Paterson Literary Review, and Weber: The Contemporary West. Her chapbooks: This Water, 2007, Body Rhymes, 2009, Wild Mercy, 2011, and Following Hay, 2013. Her poetry books are The Place of Our Meeting \(Finishing Line Press, 2018\) and Beside the Well \(Cherry Grove Collections. 2019\). And now, Daphne Lifts Up \(Finishing Line Press, 2025\). Donna has received two nominations for the Pushcart Prize, one for "Best of the Net," two nominations for the California Book Award \(Body Rhymes, 2009, The Place of Our Meeting, 2018\), five awards from the annual Allen Ginsberg Contests, and numerous regional awards for her poetry, creative non-fiction, and prose. Many of her poems appear in journals or anthologies with her black and white or color photography. Anais Nin used Donna's portraits of Anais in her late diaries and press coverage in the New York Times.  Donna has taught poetry to elementary school children and made it part of her community college classrooms \(1990-2015\). She worked as a volunteer with Alzheimer's patients at a residential facility to help them create individual and group poems and served as Board member and Events Chair for the Marin Poetry Center \(2012-2014\). Donna's latest book, "Daphne Lifts Up" includes poems about nature around us, nature within us, and relationships with many different people, from family to counseling clients, to students, colleagues at work, animals, birds, and strangers. It addresses birth, illness, death, and resiliency in all these verses.    Gerald Fleming is the author of the poetry collections The Bastard and the Bishop \(Hanging Loose Press, 2021\), One \(Hanging Loose, 2016\), The Choreographer \(Sixteen Rivers Press, 2013\), Night of Pure Breathing \(Hanging Loose, 2011\), and Swimmer Climbing onto Shore \(Sixteen Rivers, 2005\). His work has appeared in many magazines over the decades, including New Letters, Michigan Quarterly Review, Hanging Loose, Carolina Quarterly, New World Writing, Volt, Paris Lit Up, and Versal.  Fleming edited the print magazines Barnabe Mountain Review and Forward to Velma, the vitreous magazine One \(More\) Glass, and The Collected Poetry & Prose of Lawrence Fixel \(Sixteen Rivers, 2021\). He has written numerous books for teachers, including Rain, Steam, and Speed \(Jossey-Bass/Wiley, 2005\), and lives most of the year near San Francisco, part of the year in Paris. Fleming, a master of the prose poem, is never satisfied to sing the same song, and this adventuresome spirit pays dividends in these new prose poems. Constantly surprising and inventive,  The Bastard and the Bishop offers stories within stories that effortlessly merge the personal and the archetypal, breathing new life into a genre that has increasingly, and often sadly, become predictable.     Jared Emerson-Johnson is a video game music composer, sound designer, voice director and voice actor. He is the Music Supervisor and lead composer at Bay Area Sound, an audio production company specializing in sound design, music a

Set in Truvy’s beauty salon in Chinquapin, Louisiana, Steel Magnolias centers around a group of ladies who frequent the parlor to get their hair done and gossip about anyone and everyone in town – not necessarily in that order. Alternately hilarious and touching, the play is a loving exploration of the profound bond that connects these six wildly different women. This smash hit play became a smash hit movie that audiences loved!

title: The Train Talk
description:
Railroad historian and former Northwestern Pacific and Southern Pacific officer Fred Codoni will discuss the history of the railroad in Sonoma County, from the early horse-drawn streetcars – ‘horse car lines’ – to the formation of the Petaluma & Santa Rosa Railroad \(P&SR\) that went through Sebastopol. The current West County Museum in downtown Sebastopol was the terminal.  Fred Codoni’s collection of over 14,000 railroad images across this history represents a powerful and unique set of artifacts that bring to life an amazing century of change across transportation, manufacturing, and rural life. He has worked for the railroad industry since 1956, and is the last surviving member of the Northwest Pacific Railroad. As a member of the Western Railway Museum, Fred often ran P&SR passenger car No. 63 at the Western Railway museum at Rio Vista junction, the only remaining operating car from that railroad.

This talk is a project from the Western Sonoma County Historical Society. It will be preceded by a short update by the society board about what is happening at the Historical Society.

title: Train Talk
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 South High Street, Sebastopol, 95472
description:
Railroad historian and former Northwestern Pacific and Southern Pacific officer Fred Codoni will discuss the history of the railroad in Sonoma County, from the early horse-drawn streetcars – ‘horse car lines’ – to the formation of the Petaluma & Santa Rosa Railroad (P&SR) that went through Sebastopol. The current West County Museum in downtown Sebastopol was the terminal. Fred Codoni’s collection of over 14,000 railroad images across this history represents a powerful and unique set of artifacts that bring to life an amazing century of change across transportation, manufacturing, and rural life. He has worked for the railroad industry since 1956, and is the last surviving member of the Northwest Pacific Railroad. As a member of the Western Railway Museum, Fred often ran P&SR passenger car No. 63 at the Western Railway museum at Rio Vista junction, the only remaining operating car from that railroad. 
This talk is a project from the Western Sonoma County Historical Society. It will be preceded by a short update by the society board about what is happening at the Historical Society.

title: Benise
description:
Emmy Award Winning Spanish Guitar and Dance Spectacular.

It’s one hot night as Benise celebrates 25 years of fiery Spanish guitar and dance. 

Benise \(pronounced Buh-nes-say\) shattered the mold of Spanish guitar by combining world music and dance – the only show of its kind! 

2025 marks the year that Benise, “The Prince of Spanish Guitar,” launches his 25th Anniversary Tour and 8th PBS Special “25 Years of Passion!” 

 Armed with his Spanish guitar and a stage full of musicians and elaborately choreographed dancers, Benise takes the audience on a musical journey through Spanish Flamenco, Cuban Salsa, Brazilian Samba, Parisian Waltz, exotic drumming, and more! 

The 25th Anniversary tour establishes Benise’s Emmy Award winning show as one of the longest running Latin-themed theatrical productions touring the world.

For Benise, music has always been a journey. From his humble beginnings as a street performer, to being featured on the \#1 rated show in the USA – Dancing With The Stars. Guitarist and creative force behind the event, Benise, comments “I wanted to push the boundaries of Nuevo Flamenco/Spanish guitar while combining the elements of dance and theater. This show is a celebration of all the shows we’ve done over the last 25 years.” 

The Emmy Award-winning composer along with an international cast of musicians and dancers will entertain audiences with a two-hour show that “is an escape from all of their problems,” Benise says. Beyond the new material, Benise says “the live show will incorporate some fan favorites from my street performing days and rock classics like Led Zeppelin’s Kashmir and AC/DC’s Thunderstruck.” In addition, Benise adds his signature touch to classics such as “Ave Maria, “Moonlight Sonata,” and Vivaldi’s “Summer” from The Four Seasons.

Benise adds, “This is a great show for the whole family; I really think we have something for everyone. I hope people will be inspired by our story, by the music, by the production--and have the passion to follow their own dreams.” 

The Theatrical World Music and Dance spectacle that has been called “The Latin Riverdance” 

‘The Prince of Spanish Guitar’  - Dancing With The Stars

‘Bennissimo!’ - Chicago News

‘Extreme Flamenco Fusion’ - Screen India

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

title: Bone by Bone - Lecture
description: Bone by Bone: The Commingled Remains from theTomb at Tell Abraq, UAE (2200-2000 BC)  The tomb at the archaeological site of Tell Abraq, located near modern-day Abu Dhabi and Dubai, was discovered in 1989 and excavated over several field seasons. Over 300 individuals were placed in the tomb including premature and newborn infants, toddlers, teens, and adult males and females of all ages. Over time,the addition of corpses caused the disarticulation of most all of the skeletal remains. Our analysis proceeded on a bone by bone basis and questions about health and disease, trauma and violence, and diet and nutrition were addressed using innovative methods for skeletal analysis. "Osteobiographies" were created that provide a glimpse into what life was like over 4000 years ago in in the deserts of Arabia. And, one very enigmatic teenager, the only individual whose remains were not commingled, and perhaps the last person to be put in the tomb, provides a poignant reminder of the toll that disease takes.Event Details    Sunday, February 22nd from 4-5 pm    SRJC Petaluma Student Center in Mike Smith Hall    Debra L. Martin, Distinguished Professor Emerita of Anthropology at the University of Nevada in Las Vegas, is an expert on violence in past societies, which includes expertise in human osteology and bioarchaeology. She received her PhD from the University of Massachusetts. The analysis of skeletonized human remains from archaeological as well as historic and contemporary settings form a basis for understanding the effects of trauma, fractures, disability and wounds related to lethal and nonlethal violence. She is the Series Editor for Bioarchaeology and Social Theory, a book series dedicated to cutting-edge bioarchaeological work published by Springer Verlag. She is also the Editor of the journal, American Antiquity. Her recent publications include co-authoring Gender Violence in the American Southwest (AD 1100) (Routledge), co-editing Bioarchaeology of Borders and Frontiers (UPF), Massacres (UPF), and Bioarchaeological and Forensic Perspectives on Violence (Cambridge). She is co-author of the textbook, Bioarchaeology An Integrated Approach to Working with Human Remains.

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

The 12-course journey takes guests through a series of small bites, composed dishes and mains, a pre-dessert, and a final dessert - each paired with a glass of wine representing a different decade, from the 1970s to today. A few signature dishes featured this season include:

A Thousand-Layer Potato and Caviar

Three Corn Polenta with Black Truffle and Egg Yolk

Sea Urchin Bucatini; and Dates with Tonka Bean Ice Cream and Orange Bourbon Glaze

Following dinner, diners will be treated to a stay in one of Dawn Ranch’s 86 cottages and cabins. Reservations for the “Stay With Us – On The House” promotion can be made through OpenTable for Sunday or Monday evenings, for bookings through February 22.

title: Non-Toxic Comedy Show at Redwood Cafe
location: Redwood Cafe, 8240 Old Redwood Hwy, Cotati, CA
description:
Welcome to NON-TOXIC COMEDY SHOW™ from 6-8 pm at Redwood Cafe Cotati. 
This Sunday, your hosts Sienna The Comic and Jessika Frazer bring you stand-up comedy from headliner Uncle Charlie Adams with Scott Schafer, and Steve Wilkes. 
The show is No Cover, so please Tip What You Can to support local comedy : ) 
At Non-Toxic Comedy Show™ you’ll get all the jokes with none of the trauma! 
NTCS™ guarantees our audience CLEAN, NON-TOXIC comedy without having to worry about inappropriate, offensive, cringeworthy content. Our CLEAN SHOW at Redwood Cafe, Cotati, is safe for all ages, genders, and levels of sensitivity. 
Don’t get us wrong – a great set always runs the risk of offending someone. Who could’ve known it really was too soon, just for them? 
But there are some things we here at Non-Toxic Comedy Show™ think are always too soon and will never age well. At NTCS you’ll never hear anything hateful or malicious , or jokes that punch down. Plus we keep things PG clean! 
Respectful innuendo is just funnier. The writing is hard, the material is smart, the laughter is real. That’s the toxic-free guarantee! We guarantee our audience Non-Toxic, family-safe comedy. 
While we trust our performers to adhere to these guidelines, if a joke seems like it’s about to cross the line, the performer will be cut off with a cowbell, and may not be invited back. Our goal at Non-Toxic Comedy Show™? No Cowbell!

title: Beneath the Canopy at Jack London State Historic Park
description: Explore the fascinating world of mosses and lichens, along with other small wonders of the forest on a guided walk at Jack London State Historic Park.  Learn to notice their unique forms, textures, and colors, and gain insight into how these often overlooked organisms interact with their environment. Whether you are a naturalist or simply curious about the details beneath your feet and along the trail, this event offers something for everyone. Slow down, look closely, and deepen your appreciation for the small but essential elements that help shape and support the park’s ecosystems.  This hike will be about 1.2 miles roundtrip on uneven terrain. Sturdy walking shoes and weather appropriate layers are recommended.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Handbuilding 101
description:

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Ceramics

Age\(s\)

17\+

$265 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $295 – Total Registration Cost

Learn the fundamentals of creating handbuilt, functional objects with clay in this 8 week course. Thoughtfully explore the tried and true techniques of ceramic work!

What you’ll do

Designed for all levels \(beginners and those more experienced\) Deborah thoughtfully explores the tried and true techniques of ceramic work with her students through structured assignments, allowing her students to develop their own creative voice in the process. title: The Chromatic Voice: Oil Painting Journey
description:
Mondays, January 5 – MAdvance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,arch 9, 2026 9:30 AM – 12:30 PM No class January 19 and February 16

Experience Level

Intermediate and Advanced

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 – Registration Cost $35 – Optional Materials Packet

Advance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,light, and challenging subjects to deepen technique and expression.

What you’ll do

This 8-week course is designed for artists ready to deepen their technical skills and personal expression in a calm, supportive, and solvent-free studio. It serves as the natural continuation of the Fall 2025 course “Palette & Possibility,” and is also open to experienced oil painters who wish to advance their practice within a framework focused on cognitive stimulation and emotional well-being. We will move beyond simple objects to tackle subjects that introduce new cognitive challenges, such as atmosphere, reflective surfaces, and simplified portrait elements. Emphasis remains on process over product, nurturing focus, spatial reasoning, and emotional insight. Through an explorative journey into composition, light, and “The Chromatic Voice”—your unique use of color— students will strengthen their artistic voices while continuing to reap the rewards of enhanced mental agility and profound emotional well-being.

Optional Materials Packet & Supply List

$35 includes all necessary paints, mediums, brushes, surfaces \(canvas panels\), and cleaning supplies for the 8 weeks. Students who wish to bring their own materials should view the supply list. You can view the full supply list here.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.
source: Creative Sonoma, North Bay Bohemian, Press Democrat

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

Room 213, Dance Studio

Step into the rhythm and fun with our Tiny Tappers class, designed especially for young dancers aged 3 to 5 years! This lively and engaging class introduces the basics of tap dance, fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a joyful environment. Through age-appropriate techniques, rhythmic exercises, and upbeat music, children will learn foundational tap steps like shuffles, toe taps, heel digs and more! Whether your child is a first-time dancer or loves to move to the beat, Tiny Tappers is the perfect way to develop musicality, motor skills, and a love for dance. Tap into the fun and watch your little one shine! No experience is necessary – just bring your tap shoes and a smile! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. title: Tidepool Volunteer Orientation
description:
This is a two-part training 

The tidepools on the Sonoma Coast State Park beaches are teeming with multitudes of flora and fauna. From virtually invisible colonies of aggregating anemones to sea stars tucked under kelp, there are fragile intertidal creatures everywhere.

Tidepool education volunteers teach school and adult groups how to safely observe and interact with the fascinating life forms of the intertidal zone. Participants learn about the importance of protecting the fragile plants and animals that inhabit this special ecosystem. Tidepool Roving volunteers stationed on beaches during low tides provide park visitors with a safe and educational experience exploring the tidepools. Additionally, docents provide interpretation when our Touch Table is featured at events or along the coast.

No experience necessary! As a new volunteer, you will shadow experienced volunteers until you feel comfortable on your own.

We look forward to seeing you on Monday February 23 for part one of our two-part training

Part 1 of the training: Monday February 23  6 – 8pm on zoom

Part 2 of the training: Field Visit Sunday March 1 from 3 – 5 PM at Campbell Cove, Bodega Head, Sonoma Coast State Park Map to Campbell Cove

title: Please join us to hear photographer Phil Venable present travelogue photos
description:
February speaker, Phil Venable, has been shooting photos since he was a kid, when his dad gave him a Kodak Brownie. He studied black-and-white photography in college and had plans to be a photojournalist until life intervened. After spending an adulthood in law enforcement, Phil picked up his camera again and began making art.  Phil’s preference is nature/landscape, but he is drawn to shapes, lines, and shadows found in urban landscapes. “My favorite subjects are old rusted cars, trains, abandoned buildings, and brightly colored doors.  I use several plugins in Photoshop to create surreal images from otherwise ordinary photos.  I create photos in both color and black and white, depending on subject matter and mood.”

Phil is President of the Napa Valley Photographic Society, and a member of the Fairfield Suisun Valley Art Association, the Vacaville Art League, Gold Rush Photo Club, and the Lightwriters Photography Club.  Phil is also a member of the Professional Photographers of America, and the Photographic Society of America.

Phil’s work has been shown at Viewpoint Gallery, Sacramento; Yountville Community Center, The Old Sugar Mill, Arata Fine Arts Gallery, and the Roseville Brewing Company, including shows at the Vacaville Art Gallery, the Napa Public Library, Solano Town Center Gallery, the Gallery at Village 360, and he is a resident artist at The Little Shop in Benicia.  He has won several awards at local shows and contests, including a Juror's Choice Award at the 2013 Vacaville Art Gallery Juried Art Show.  Phil’s photos can be seen at www.philipvenablephotography.com.  He is also on Facebook as Philip Venable Photography.  Contact Phil at philven@comcast.net.

Napa Valley Photographic Society \(NVPS\) promotes the art and science of photography, providing education, image appreciation, inspiration, exchange of technologies. Most months we invite guest speakers to evaluate our images.  Guests are welcome to attend.  Check the website for more information http://www.napavalleyphotographicsociety.org.

title: Santa Rosa Symphony - Mahler's Third
description: Mahler's Third February 21, 22 & 23, 2026 Weill Hall, Green Music Center Francesco Lecce-Chong, conductor Gabrielle Beteag, mezzo-soprano Treble Voices of the SSU Symphonic Chorus, Jenny Bent, director Gustav Mahler: Symphony No. 3 in D minor Mahler's Third Symphony explores the human condition, nature, and the divine. With six movements, it reflects Mahler's philosophical quest to "embrace everything." Mezzo-soprano Gabrielle Beteag and the Treble Voices of the SSU Symphonic Chorus, directed by Jenny Bent, return to Weill Hall to perform what is regarded as one of the greatest symphonies of all time. Programs, dates, artists, and prices are subject to change without notice. Tickets are nonrefundable and subject to availability.

title: Beneath the Canopy at Jack London State Historic Park
description: Explore the fascinating world of mosses and lichens, along with other small wonders of the forest on a guided walk at Jack London State Historic Park.  Learn to notice their unique forms, textures, and colors, and gain insight into how these often overlooked organisms interact with their environment. Whether you are a naturalist or simply curious about the details beneath your feet and along the trail, this event offers something for everyone. Slow down, look closely, and deepen your appreciation for the small but essential elements that help shape and support the park’s ecosystems.  This hike will be about 1.2 miles roundtrip on uneven terrain. Sturdy walking shoes and weather appropriate layers are recommended.

description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: Watercolor Fundamentals Part 1
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesdays
10:30AM-1:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$270.00


*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*

There will be a materials fee of $15 plus tax for the series.


Watercolor Fundamentals - Part 1

This class focuses on the simple delight of mixing color with water, brushing it on paper, and watching what happens as it moves and dries. You will learn easy ways to create paintings that are all about color and the sometimes unpredictable nature of water.

No drawing skills are needed.

In this class we will explore the basic principles of watercolor painting. Learn or refresh your understanding of brush handling, brush care and setting up, the benefits of “good paper”, watercolor lights and darks, flat and graded washes, wet-on-wet techniques such as charging, wet-on-dry techniques such as glazing, color wheel, color theory, color mixing, and more. Simple applications of these techniques invite you to experiment and play.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

*Brushes, palettes, set-ups, and paint will be provided.*


To see Anne's work and to learn more about this class, please visit her website at: http://www.miraaster.com https://www.miraaster.com/ www.miraaster.com


To register for this workshop, please contact Anne by email at: classes@miraaster.com mailto:classes@miraaster.com mailto:amillett@gmail.com

title: Aging & Disability Commission: No Wrong Door Standing Committee
description: The No Wrong Door Standing Committee supports the continued efforts in the Sonoma County community to increase equitable access to information, assistance, and supports needed for older adults and people with disabilities to live as independently as possible at home.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:
**WHAT:** Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         **Offered Daily:** 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

·         **Experience length:** 2 hours

·         **Wines:** Selections of library, limited single-vineyard, and a barrel tasting of yet-to-be-released Cabernet Sauvignon

·         **Cost:** $150 per Person

·         **Exclusive Member Price:** $95 per Member

**ADMISSION:** Members $95 | Non-members $150

title: Fit Forever
description:
In this class is about making sure you can do what you want to do, for as long as you want to do it. It’s about creating that strong foundation for a truly active lifestyle. Dance, Exercise, and Staying Fit.

low impact

building muscles

movement

confidence

We focus on the most important things: building strong muscles using safe, low-impact movements. We’ll also dedicate time to flexibility and balance, because true fitness isn’t just about strength—it’s about moving through the world with ease and confidence.

title: Watercolor Fundamentals Part 3
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesday afternoons

6 Tuesday afternoons, 2:00PM - 4:30PM

January 20, 27, February 3, 10, 17, 24

Location: Santa Rosa Store
$270.00

*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*


Watercolor Fundamentals Part 3

You’ve experienced Part 1, you’ve experienced Part 2, and now let’s dive into more water in Part 3! More water leads to more spontaneity and deepens our focus in the moment. Loose florals, imagined landscapes, and abstractions are painted wet-into-wet style in multiple layers. Refining our abilities to work with the water keeps us open to possibilities and surprises in our paintings as they emerge.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

*Brushes, palettes, set-ups, and paint will be provided.*


To see Anne's work and to learn more about this class, please visit her website at: http://www.miraaster.com https://www.miraaster.com/ www.miraaster.com


To register for this workshop, please contact Anne by email at: classes@miraaster.com mailto:classes@miraaster.com mailto:amillett@gmail.com
