title: Rooted and Rising: Honoring the Lineage of Women in Buddhism
description:
with Kate Munding, Jennifer Berezan, DaRa Williams and Erin Treat

Across centuries and continents, women have deep roots in the Buddha Dharma. They have been great contributors and carriers of the lineage and yet have too often remained hidden beneath the surface of history. Their stories are fierce, resilient, and revolutionary. Do you know them?

From the first Buddhist nuns who challenged the norms of their time, to modern-day teachers, mothers, activists, and visionaries reshaping spiritual life today, women have always been keystones to the continuation of the Dharma. This benefit event invites all genders to step into that legacy—to see, honor, and draw strength from the women who have shaped the Dharma with their courage and uncompromising truth.

Together with an inspiring group of contemporary Dharma teachers, we’ll explore these stories and ask: What guidance do these spiritual ancestors offer us now—when clarity, groundedness, and collective courage are so urgently needed?

title: Sunlit Florals Workshop
description:
Instructor: Susan Sweet
March 7th, 2026
10:00AM - 4:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$125 per class

Join Susan Sweet for an inspiring day of watercolors! Beginning to advanced students welcome.

During this workshop students will learn the importance of good art materials, brushes, paints, and paper. Composition/cropping: Understanding form and light source. How to transfer designs to watercolor paper. Techniques and tricks with masking fluid to obtain soft and crisp edges and textures.

Students will explore basic watercolor washes & glazing techniques for depth and luminosity (what paints play well with others). We will also explore techniques for creating texture with spraying, salt, thirsty brush, etc.

Each student will be given two images of the piece to be painted, one color and one black and white for a value study. The image will be transferred to the watercolor paper using graphite paper, and masking fluid applied where needed. While the fluid dries we will explore painting simpler forms to practice graded washes and color combinations to be used in the final painting. Students will observe demos as we move through the painting and will receive one on one helpful guidance to gain skill and confidence!

Susan Sweet is a local mixed media and watercolor artist whose work is inspired by nature.

To register, please contact Susan Sweet by email: mailto:susansweetartist@gmail.com mailto:susansweetartist@gmail.com mailto:susansweetartist@gmail.com susansweetartist@gmail.com mailto:susansweetartist@gmail.com mailto:susansweetartist@gmail.com or by phone (707) 367-0672.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: Wondrous Wildflower Walk to the Waterfall
description:
Join Certified CA Naturalist John Lynch on one of his wondrous wildflower hikes. We’ll follow Pony Gate Trail’s grassy slope, into the Oak woodland and through a mixed evergreen forest, along Canyon Trail’s shady riparian corridor lined with redwoods, to the 25 -foot dramatic plunge of Sonoma Creek and back to the our starting point at the Visitor Center. This outing is approximately 2 miles with 595-foot elevation gain.

Meet at the Visitor Center. Tickets are $10 for general admission, $5 for youth (12-17 year olds), students, Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf or RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Wear layers, appropriate footwear for muddy and/or slippery trails, bring at least a quart of water and if desired, a snack. Heavy rain cancels and will be announced early on the day of the hike. Parking fees apply.

Focusing on recognizing and treating life-threatening situations in the critical minutes before 911 arrives, we will cover adult and infant CPR, AED use and handling choking, as well as what to do in cases of severe bleeding, sudden illness, heart attack, stroke and more.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Join Us for Wine Road's Annual Barrel Tasting. The Longest Running Wine Event in California.

Celebrate one of Sonoma County's most cherished wine traditions at Wine Road's Annual Barrel Tasting. Now in its 48th year, this iconic event brings together 50 wineries across Northern Sonoma County for a tasting experience focused entirely on the Past, Present, and Future of wine.

Barrel Tasting is not a food-pairing or themed event-it's all about the wine and how it evolves over time. Taste a current vintage, compare it to the same wine still aging in the barrel, and savor the depth and complexity of select library wines. It's a rare opportunity to explore the winemaking journey side by side, straight from the source.

Meet the winemakers, step into the cellar, and experience the heart and soul of Sonoma County winemaking up close. Come ready to taste, learn, and have fun-Barrel Tasting happens just once a year, and it's not to be missed.

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Monoprints: Drawing & Printing Abstraction Two-day workshop
description:
**Monoprinting** is a unique expression of printmaking typically painterly in effect, made by applying or painting ink to an historically, copper etching plate.  In contemporary work it can vary from zinc to acrylic or a gel plate, or no plate at all. In contrast to other printing processes, mono-printing creates one final image.  However, it is possible to create a “ghost” print (or lighter print) after the final image - but it is its own image, not identical to the original.  

In this class, we will use the idea of experimenting, and using drawing, tracing, stencil and the printing presses available to us at the Art Escape to create abstract images from nature and  using recycled materials.  These found materials create all kinds of markings, shapes and images - as they make their way through the press.  Botanicals can compliment the stencils and create openings for more texture, shapes, and imagery to create layered pieces through multiple runs through the press.  When peeling back the paper for the look, it is the surprise element that keeps me coming back to this process.  This process also works well with other printmaking processes.  Using materials like Tyvek that can be traced or cut into shapes and images, we can layer these elements onto the plate or paper and then put through the press over and over again creating repeat images.  While creating interesting artful images that are so intriguing, they might even be considered poetic.

title: Cloverdale Repair Fair
description:
Do you have a lamp, small appliance, textile, or bike in need of repair?

Bring it to the Repair Fair!

Volunteers and specialized repair professionals will be on-hand to repair\* your items.  We ask that you stay with your item while it's being fixed, so you can learn tips for future maintenance, how to shop for repairable goods, and even how to repair things yourself!  

If you’d like to bring an item to repair, please register the item here: https://www.reusealliance.org/rf-reg . \(Pre-registering allows us to prepare for your item!\)

This is a free public event.

\*We cannot guarantee your item\(s\) will be repaired, depending on the existing damage or breakage, ability of volunteer fixers, and availability of materials for repair. Note we cannot work on microwaves and we can’t repair cell phones but we’re happy to refer you to local professionals who can. In addition, the textile department is not able to perform the following:

Replacing zippers

Repairing shoes, leather, or vinyl materials

Performing alterations \(making garments bigger/smaller\)

Replacing rivets/grommets

Hemming certain fabrics \(stretchy fabric, sleek/luxury fabrics e.g. prom dresses\)

If you are in need of garment hemming, we require that you please pin your garment to the desired length before you arrive.

Join Us!

Does fixing things sound like a fun way to spend a Saturday afternoon?  Or want to help out in other ways?  We need you!

Email volunteer@reusealliance.org or sign up here: https://www.reusealliance.org/rf-volunteer

title: From Spirit with Love a Council Gathering of the Ancestors
description:
With more than 50 years of experience and five advanced degrees, Dr. Maria is known worldwide as a medical intuitive, channel, empath, teacher, and Lakota/Diné Traditional Elder.

During this time of great upheaval in our world, and specifically in our country, the environments we live in and create for ourselves can have dramatic impacts on our cellular healing and processing. Dr. Maria Michael will talk about how climate change, social justice and our environments impact our physical, mental, emotional and spiritual bodies. She will talk about the importance of self care, focusing on the most impacted organs, how to recognize what is needed, and ways in which to support yourself, physically, emotionally, spiritually, and mentally. She will focus on herbal medicine and other somatic and ancient methods to support the immune system. There will be time for an open dialogue with the audience and to answer questions. What makes this evening especially powerful is that it takes place within the amplified bioenergetic field of the EESystem. As Dr. Maria speaks about cellular resonance, coherence, and restoring balance, guests will simultaneously be immersed in a scalar-energy environment designed to support optimal cellular communication and energetic harmony. The experience becomes more than a lecture — it becomes embodied learning.

This event offers a welcoming introduction to Dr. Maria’s work. For those who feel called to go deeper, Dr Maria will hold on March 15th a group healing circle ceremony/workshop. It is a guided interactive process, in which each participant will experience a variety of techniques using light, sound, touch, energy and ancient wisdom healing techniques. Whether you are new to her work or already familiar with energy-based healing, this evening is an invitation to explore what becomes possible when wisdom, frequency, and intention align. We look forward to welcoming you into the field.

About Dr Maria Michael

Dr. Maria D. Michael is a world renowned and respected medical intuitive, channel, empath, healer, psychic and teacher for over 40 years. She has been awarded 5 advanced degrees \(all Summa Cum Laude\), including a Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology. She has doctorate-level training in Neuropsychology and Special Education and extensive post-doctoral studies in Psychoanalysis and Jungian Psychology. Additionally, Dr. Michael is trained and experienced in EMDR, Hypnotherapy, LENS Neurofeedback, Neurolinguistic Programming, Eriksonian Hypnosis Training. She is a Lakota/Diné \(Navajo\) Traditional elder, has participated in and led traditional Native ceremonies and doctored alongside Lakota Medicine people. She has been sought out worldwide for her powerful Medicine Energies and Healing abilities.

BELIEFS

Dr. Maria Michael believes that we all come from the same Creation, and that everyone has the potential and capacity to communicate with Creation. While the Lakota call Creation “The Great Mystery,” other traditions may refer to Creation, with names such as, “God,” “the Universe,” “Allah,” “Yahweh,” “Divine Love,” “Universal Love” or “Cosmic Consciousness.”

We not only choose our human families, but also we choose, initially at least, our own unique form or tradition of understanding and communication with the Great Mystery. No form or tradition is better than another. Humans are merely attempting to understand “That” which is beyond comprehension.

All messages from the Great Mystery are compassionate and loving, even though at times these messages may appear difficult. Creation’s message appears to us in whatever way we choose to comprehend it. Sometimes, we are only capable of comprehending deeply sensitive messages that resound in our hearts, and sometimes only strong and “seemingly” shocking messages penetrate our defenses. This loving Spirit guides us to remove those obstacles that stand in our way of becoming all that Creation and We intended us to be.

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

His first three singles Don’t Look Down, Different Planets, & Ghosts of Neighborhood Dogs \(feat. Jordana\) were released earlier this year to critical praise from Uproxx, Consequence of Sound, and Flood amongst others, plus spins on KCRW and 91X. All of his new material reflects on his life-changing experience of becoming a new father.

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: Transatlantic Exploration Company
description: ASTRID KULJANIC's TRANSATLANTIC EXPLORATION COMPANY     featuring the Ben Rosenblum Trio Saturday, March 7,2026. 7:00pm Open seating.  All Seats  $25 Hailing from Croatia, Brazil, Seattle and New York City, USA, the Astrid Kuljanic Transatlantic Exploration Company unites four musical worlds, bound by a shared dedication and curiosity for music. Astrid’s instinct for exploration brought her to New York, where she quickly became immersed in musical communities from India and Brazil, Klezmer music, avant-garde improvisation, and electronic experimentation.  She carefully drew from these circles her new band members: accordionist Benjamin Rosenblum, bassist Mat Muntz and percussionist Rogerio Boccato. The band developed a strong connection through regular performances of Astrid’s original music, arrangements of jazz and Brazilian standards, and traditional and popular songs from Eastern Europe.  Performance highlights include The Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., Gramercy Theatre and Waldorf Astoria in New York City, and each performance is charged with interactive improvisation and rhythmic intensity.  The band celebrated their first album – an energetic set of music with rolling momentum – with a sold out concert release party at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.

title: Virgins to Villains - Live Theatre at THE 222
description:
Robin Goodrin Nordli returns to THE 222 in this witty, insightful, and revealing one-woman show. This Oregon Shakespeare Festival veteran actor draws from her experiences of performing in 61 productions of 30 different plays by William Shakespeare. From the Bard’s innocent virgins to his vindictive villains, Robin masterfully explores her own life journey through the prism of her relationship with Shakespeare’s female characters.

Touching, powerful and entertaining.— Dangerous Common Sense

Sponsored by Kate & Dennis Abbe, Randy Varney & John King, and Michael & Janet Verlander

Theatre - Programmed by Aldo Billingslea and Amy Kossow

THE 222 / 222 Healdsburg Avenue / Healdsburg CA

As she struggles with opening up to Bo, Kate also seeks to reconnect with her estranged daughter who lives nearby. Brimming with humanity and humor, *A Good Deal* is a bittersweet tale of love, loss, and family connections. Developed through the Raven Players’ ScripTease program.

Bernard's life gets bumpy, though, when his friend Robert comes to stay, and complications such as weather and a new, speedier Boeing jet disrupt his careful planning. Soon, all three stewardesses are in the city simultaneously and catastrophe looms.  By Marc Camoletti  Translated by Beverley Cross and Francis EvansRecommendations: Mild language and innuendo. title: Wreckless Strangers at Rancho Nicasio
description:
Coming off the heels of a lively, full-house record release show at Sweetwater, **Wreckless Strangers** continue their album release celebration with a special dinner show at the legendary West Marin roadhouse **Rancho Nicasio** on **Saturday, March 7,** joined by special guests, including a horn section alongside the six-piece band. The Bay Area sextet is thrilled to bring their signature sound back to the iconic venue. Music begins at **7:30 pm**, with dinner reservations available from **6 pm to 8 pm**.

Wreckless Strangers return to their roots with their forthcoming studio album, ***Dirty Souls***. The six-song collection marks the band’s most raw and visceral effort to date — a modern take on the arena rock of the 1970s and ’80s that inspired their earliest musical influences.

The songwriting is among their most intimate and personal, exploring themes of relationships, loss, empowerment, and perseverance. Co-lead singers **Amber Morris** and **David Noble** function as a single organism, bringing the songs to life with bluesy grit, soul, and humanity bolstered by rock-solid, road-hewn grooves. 

***Dirty Souls*** is the band’s third studio outing under the tutelage of Grammy-winning producer **Dave Way**, who fosters a level of depth and organic cohesion that firmly establishes Wreckless Strangers in San Francisco’s storied rock ‘n’ roll legacy.  The first single, "Dirty Soul," came out on January 23 and is available on all streaming platforms. The full album comes out in late March, but concert attendees will have the exclusive opportunity to purchase advance copies of the CD. Review copies are available now, upon request.

Visit **WrecklessStrangers.com** and follow the band on social media for updates.

Dirty Cello performs all over the world, from Iceland to Israel, from Scottish castles to underground caves presenting an energetic and wild show that's been described as, "Dirty Cello’s music is all over the map: funky, carnival, romantic, sexy, tangled, electric, fiercely rhythmic, and textured, and only occasionally classical." by Oakland Magazine.

title: Safari West Presents! Oiled Wildlife Care Network
description: Conservation Dinner Series: Lorraine Barbosa from  Oiled Wildlife Care Network joins us in the elephant room after dinner to give a talk about the veterinary care of oiled sea life. The conservation dinner series is complimentary to all dinner guests. If you want to attend this presentation, please call our reservations team at \(707\) 566-3667 or \(800\) 616-2695 and they can book it for you. Dinner starts at 7:00 PM.    About the Speaker: Lorraine obtained her veterinary degree and Masters of Preventive Veterinary Medicine from UC Davis in 2010 and has since spent her time working as both a small animal and wildlife veterinarian. Her main focus has been on marine mammals, specifically pinnipeds \(seals and sea lions\), but during her years as a veterinarian, she has worked with a variety of wildlife, everything birds to bears. In addition to clinical work, Lorraine has also enjoyed collaborating on several marine mammal field research projects in Central and South America. In 2017 she became certified as a Diplomate of the American College of Preventive Veterinary Medicine, and in 2018 she began working as a veterinarian for the Oiled Wildlife Care Network at UC Davis, where she currently serves as the Senior Manager of Care Operations.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: Bothe Napa Valley State Park
description:
Go Wild Hikers
Spring is almost here. **Daylight Savings Time Begins**
**Set your clocks Ahead One Hour or you'll miss the hike.** Join us for a hike in Napa Valley. Bothe is 1900 acres of beautiful redwoods, bay laurel, madrones and moss-covered Douglas fir, orchids, trilliums and wildflowers (in season), spotted owls, pileated woodpeckers and forest pigeons, springs, creeks and ferns. You will not be disappointed! A challenging hike, best for individuals with at least a moderate level of fitness.

**Where We Meet/Directions**
Bothe Napa Valley State Park
3801 St. Helena Hwy (Highway 29/128), Calistoga, CA 94515
The park is located approximately 5 miles north of St. Helena and 4 miles south of Calistoga on Highway 29/128.
After passing the **entrance & Pay Station** follow the road to a large parking area. There are bathrooms past this parking lot about 200 yards.
Give yourself plenty of time to arrive, pay park fee and use the toilet. It often takes longer than you think.

**After Hike Gathering?**
The Calistoga Creamery
1473 Lincoln Avenue, Calistoga 94515
https://www.yelp.com/biz/calistoga-creamery-calistoga
An outstanding ice cream shop! Opens at 12 pm Sat and Sun.
Organic ice cream and organic frozen yogurt, thick custom milk shakes, root beer floats and sundaes. No high fructose corn syrup, artificial colors or flavors. No hydrogenated oils and no GMOs.

**Group Hike #334**
Coyote Peak Trail to Ritchey Canyon Trail - A loop hike
Distance - 6 miles/9.7 kilometers
Elevation change - 1100 feet/335 meters
Difficulty - 7+ out of 10 - moderate
Exposures - 20 % sun/ 80% shade- rocky, creek crossings, mud, poison oak, ticks & insects.
Bring plenty of water. At least 68 oz./2 liters
Dogs - Not permitted
Facilities at trail head - Shade, picnic table, restrooms down the road.
Cost - $5 cash
Parking - State Parks fee of $8 or free with your State Park Pass.
Remember to wear appropriate hiking shoes, bring plenty of water, a hat, a snack/lunch and layered clothing.
Please Do Not Use Any scented products the day of a group hike!
Of course, we will all look out for each other but ultimately, hikers are responsible for their own safety and well-being during hikes.

**When We Meet**
Sunday March 8, 2026
**Daylight Savings Time Begins**
**Set your clocks Ahead One Hour or you'll miss the hike.**
9:00 am - 12:30 pm PDT
If your plans change after you sign up even if you're on the waitlist, please update your RSVP.
Do Not Attend if you are sick, running a fever, were exposed to or have tested positive for Covid-19 or any other contagion!
Hike may be changed, rescheduled or cancelled in case of excessive heat, rain, smoke/AQI, illness, zombie apocalypse etc... Check your email the night before for any possible changes.

**Notice to New Hikers Only**
**"When a New Hiker (never hiked with me before) doesn't show up (No Show) to their first hike with the group, they will be removed (not banned) from the group immediately."**

title: Online: Unshakeable Peace Rooted in Earth-Based Practices
description:
with Carol Cano, MA and Ayya Santacitta

In a world of constant change and uncertainty, this half-day of mindfulness practice offers an invitation to return to what is steady and reliable. Drawing from Forest Buddhist teachings and earth-based awareness, we will cultivate a peace that does not depend on conditions. A peace that arises from being fully present, embodied, and grounded.

Through sitting and walking meditation, and periods of silence, we will explore the body as part of the living earth and awareness as a refuge that is always available. Rather than striving for calm, the practice invites us to rest in what already holds us—moment by moment, breath by breath.

This is offered as a time to slow down, listen deeply, and reconnect with the unshakeable peace within our own hearts.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Community Sound Healing
description:
Waves of Sound, Moments of Peace. ~ A monthly ritual for your Soul.

Bring a yoga mat or blanket, plus pillows and anything you need to be cozy, then simply lie back as waves of sound from crystal bowls, chimes, and gongs flow through you. No effort or experience needed.

It’s like being immersed in a living ocean of sound where every ripple carries you deep into rest, relaxation, and a quiet sense of peace.

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Monoprints: Drawing & Printing Abstraction Two-day workshop
description:
**Monoprinting** is a unique expression of printmaking typically painterly in effect, made by applying or painting ink to an historically, copper etching plate.  In contemporary work it can vary from zinc to acrylic or a gel plate, or no plate at all. In contrast to other printing processes, mono-printing creates one final image.  However, it is possible to create a “ghost” print (or lighter print) after the final image - but it is its own image, not identical to the original.  

In this class, we will use the idea of experimenting, and using drawing, tracing, stencil and the printing presses available to us at the Art Escape to create abstract images from nature and  using recycled materials.  These found materials create all kinds of markings, shapes and images - as they make their way through the press.  Botanicals can compliment the stencils and create openings for more texture, shapes, and imagery to create layered pieces through multiple runs through the press.  When peeling back the paper for the look, it is the surprise element that keeps me coming back to this process.  This process also works well with other printmaking processes.  Using materials like Tyvek that can be traced or cut into shapes and images, we can layer these elements onto the plate or paper and then put through the press over and over again creating repeat images.  While creating interesting artful images that are so intriguing, they might even be considered poetic.

title: "Champagne Girl in a Budweiser Family" Author Reading with Suzanne Weerts
description: Champagne Girl in a Budweiser Family by Suzanne Weerts is a funny and touching memoir told through vivid, story-driven moments of growing up in the American South in the 1970’s and ’80’s. With warmth and sharp humor, Weerts explores class, culture, and family expectations — what it’s like to be a girl with champagne tastes in a Budweiser family, and how those early contradictions shape a life. Suzanne will be doing a book event March 8 in Healdsburg at the Healdsburg Bubble Bar. The book balances laugh-out-loud observations with genuine emotional depth and will appeal to readers who enjoy character-driven memoirs about women, family, and identity. Please join us!

title: Breathless Sparkling Wines "Women’s History Celebration Sundays"
description:
**Breathless Sparkling Wines** is hosting a speaker and luncheon series which will be held **every Sunday in March** at the winery’s tranquil outdoor garden in Healdsburg to honor **Women’s History Month**. 

The **“Breathless Women’s History Celebration Sundays”** series aligns with the **National Women’s History Alliance**’s 2026 theme, “Leading the Change: Women Shaping a Sustainable Future,” which recognizes women advancing environmental, economic and social sustainability through leadership, innovation and community impact.

Each Breathless Wines Sparkling Garden Luncheon will be paired with a featured female speaker whose work reflects the evolving role of women in shaping industries and communities, sparkling wines, and wines paired with a lunch prepared by **Chef Beryl Adler** of Healdsburg's **Acorn Café.** Visit **BreathlessWines.com** for more.

title: In Her Power
description:
In Her Power

A Collaboration by Priscila Soares & JeanCherie

In Her Power is a group exhibition celebrating women’s presence, strength, and creative expression. Anchored by a collaborative, life-size sculptural work by Priscila Soares and JeanCherie, the exhibition brings together works by women artists exploring power as something lived, embodied, and deeply personal.

At the heart of the gallery stands a mountain lioness woman — a guardian figure shaped by two artists working together, each bringing her own voice, materials, and vision. Surrounding this central work, invited artists contribute pieces that reflect their own relationship to power, resilience, intuition, and selfhood.

Rather than offering a single definition, In Her Power invites viewers to witness many expressions of strength — quiet and fierce, ancestral and contemporary, individual and shared. It is both a celebration of women artists and an invitation to step into presence, creativity, and connection.

Opening Reception:

March 1, 12–4pm

Gallery Hours:

Sundays in March, 12–4pm

Mare Island Art Studios

title: Hook and Ladder Vineyards and Winery
description: Callie Watts is a singer/songwriter from Northern California who was raised on classical music, The Beatles and The Beach Boys before discovering Joni Mitchell, Elton John, Stevie Wonder, Paul Simon, Billy Joel, Carole King, and all the great writers of the ’60s and 70’s who have influenced her sound and writing style. After graduating high school, Callie began playing and performing solo, as well as in local and bay area bands of different genres. She’s played blues with Eric Lindell and the Reds, funky soul with Phatty, and jazz/swing with Savoy Swingers along with many other various projects. Callie has taken turns throughout her career as a keyboardist, guitarist, writer, and lead/backing vocalist, and she’s currently a member of the dynamic Sonoma County funk rock band Burrows and Dilbeck, having joined in 2010 as part of the former band Frobeck. Over time, she’s had the honor of opening for acts such as Bootsy Collins, Elvin Bishop, Huey Lewis and The News, War, Ozomatli, Bill Champlin, Booker T, and the B52s. Callie continues to perform frequently as an acoustic solo artist, focusing on developing a core audience and a buzz for her original material. Come hang out and listen at venues such as Aroma Roasters, Rincon Valley Tap Room and Bottle Shop, and Hopmonk Tavern.

title: Flora & Fauna - Watercolor Course with Hannah Day
description:
In this 4 week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium. The class will focus on strengthening one’s observational skills, giving the artist a foundation off of which to build their paintings in a step by step layering process, that trains the artist to see value and color

Our subject matter will be flora and fauna - a sampling of plants and animals. These subjects are great for beginners and experienced artists alike; their organic shapes make them forgiving drawing subjects, but their beauty can be a muse for life. 

This class will work both from photographs and from life, practicing observational drawing in addition to watercolor technique. With 4 class sessions, participants will have the opportunity to develop their skills and build muscle memory with a medium that often feels like it has a mind of its own. 

All materials provided.

Location: Bohemian Flowers Farm, 121 Bohemian Hwy, Freestone, CA

Dates: Four Sundays - March 8, 15, 22, 29

Time: 1 - 4 pm

Ages: Adults

Skill Levels: All Levels

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: Virgins to Villains - Live Theatre at THE 222
description:
Robin Goodrin Nordli returns to THE 222 in this witty, insightful, and revealing one-woman show. This Oregon Shakespeare Festival veteran actor draws from her experiences of performing in 61 productions of 30 different plays by William Shakespeare. From the Bard’s innocent virgins to his vindictive villains, Robin masterfully explores her own life journey through the prism of her relationship with Shakespeare’s female characters.

Touching, powerful and entertaining.— Dangerous Common Sense

Sponsored by Kate & Dennis Abbe, Randy Varney & John King, and Michael & Janet Verlander

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

title: Book reading: Shah Razad and the Djins Who Lover Her with author Jazzmyn Inisis
description: Jazzmyn Inisis will read from her book, Shah Razad and the Djins Who Loved Her in the OCA lobby. Jazzmyn is a local writer who was deeply influenced living in the middle east as a child of a military father stationed there in the 1950's. Join us for an afternoon of mystery and storytelling with Jazzmyn, accompanied by middle eastern food and fine wines available for purchase. Settle in and be transported! Free admission, all donations happily accepted.   She writes "I am nine years old living in Damacus, Syria. My father is on a diplomatic assignment with the United Nations to ease tensions on the volatile border between Jordan and Israel. We are transferred from Damacus, Syria, to Jerusalem, Jordan in late 1955. I came to know and love my Bedouin neighbors. They kindly lend me their only donkey. I attend their daughter's wedding and join their family in the Suk to shop in the inner city of Jerusalem. I am envious of their beautiful, embroidered dresses and have fallen deeply in love with my kind and generous neighbors. Ten years ago, I picked up volume number one of "The Book of the Thousand Nights and One Night" translated by Sir Richard Francis Burton. The first of sixteen volumes of the stories Shah Razad told her emperor over one thousand nights in order to curtail his slaughter of every young, noble woman in her country. After completing the sixteen volumes of "Shah Razad" i felt compelled to continue this extraordinary tradition of storytelling, intended to transmit moral values, by adding my own story: Shah Razad...and the Djinns Who Loved Her.

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

title: Healdsburg Community Band Pops Concert
description: The 45-piece Healdsburg Community Band performs its annual Pops Concert Sunday, March 8, 5:00 PM. Jon Saler conducts American-origin music for the country’s 250th anniversary. This includes popular marches by Henry Fillmore and John Philip Sousa as well as newer pieces by Aaron Copeland, George Gershwin, favorites from the big band era, songs by Neil Diamond, The Beach Boys, Scott Joplin and Irving Berlin. Admission is free.

title: Evening with Medium Michaela McGivern
description:
This will be an intimate evening connecting with loved ones who have passed over, bringing messages of love, hope and who knows what else they may have to share.

Each guest is invited to ask a loved one a question or communicate a message .These conversation can bring reassurance, closure or a new perspective. Be prepared to be touched and inspired.

What happens in a Mediumship session?

With your permission, I connect with a loved one who has passed and transmit messages between the two of you.

The conversation might be one to get an update on how that Spirit is doing, clarify something that occurred, forgive one another, or get suggestions from the loved one about a concern you have. These conversations bring relief, healing and a sense of peace.

title: Bodeans
description:
BoDeans

30 years of Love & Hope & Sex & Dreams

2016 finds the band preparing to release their 13th studio record-Due out in September, while also celebrating the 30th anniversary of the release of Love & Hope & Sex & Dreams with a celebratory exhibit on display at the Milwaukee County Historical Society, a limited edition Sprecher beer-BoDeans Original Ginger Brew, and numerous shows, including a much anticipated return to Summerfest – BMO Harris Pavilion on July 3rd.

Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett has officially declared June 16, 2016 BoDeans Day in Milwaukee! The band will debut a new song, “My Hometown” an ode to Milwaukee, available on iTunes and benefitting the Milwaukee County Historical Society that day. According to Kurt Neumann, the song is a reflection of “Where you were raised...your friends and your family. Your memories. Your sense of being and belonging to somewhere. About the process of going away and coming back to realize that everything you ever needed was always there to begin with.”

BoDeans’ remarkable 30\+ year musical history is founded upon compelling songs and high energy performances that have earned them an exuberant, loyal, and unpretentious rock and roll following.

Milwaukee’s hometown heroes have been a Summerfest staple since the mid 80’s. Playing to passionate capacity crowds on numerous stages throughout the years-most notably the Marcus Amphitheater on many occasions. The band has shared that stage with many acts including Steve Miller, and Bruce Hornsby and has been honored to have the likes of Train, Chris Isaak, Warren Zevon, Joan Osbourne, and The Wallflowers open for them there. Perhaps one of the longest associations between a locally based artist and major festival, the BoDeans anxiously await their traditional Summerfest shows.

BoDeans have created a sound that helped define a genre and that a generation embraced- songs like “Good Things,” “You Don’t Get Much,” “Idaho,” “If It Makes You,”“Stay,”“All The World,”and “Closer To Free.”

The band’s accessible adult alternative sound has achieved many milestones, including a Rolling Stone Reader’s Poll For Best New American Band in 1987, support slots with U2, Bob Dylan, Paul Simon, Tom Petty, George Thorogood, The Pretenders, David Bowie and numerous others. Appearances at Farm Aid, Summerfest, ACL Festival and others, along with TV appearances on “Saturday Night Live,” “Letterman,” “Today,” “Imus,” CNN, and ESPN, to name a few. The BoDeans’ music is featured throughout the new Netflix original series, The Ranch, which premiered in April featuring Sam Elliott, Ashton Kutcher, Danny Masterson and Debra Winger.

BoDeans have a permanent installation at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Museum in Cleveland as part of their Midwest Artists exhibit.

title: Future of Bass Awardee, Bass Phenom Mohini Dey Quartet
location: Music and Minds at The Dance Palace
description:
Mohini Dey is a renowned bass guitarist, arranger, producer and vocalist who has gained international recognition for her extraordinary talent and versatility. With her unique style and impeccable technique, she has collaborated with numerous renowned artists and performed on prestigious stages around the world. She is a 27-year-old bass guitarist from Mumbai, India.

She has been described as the “Most Successful Musician UNDER30” By ForbesIndia. She has been working professionally in the music industry for the past 18 years meaning that she started working professionally when she was only 9 years old. She is the only female bassist to rank within the 'Top 10 Bassists in the 21st Century' on Music Radar. She has over 20 million views collectively on YouTube, 406k followers on Instagram and 183K subscribers on YouTube and 201K followers on Facebook. She is currently the bassist for Willow Smith. She has worked with artists like Steve Vai, Zakir Hussain, Quincy Jones, Vinnie Colauita, Stanley Clarke, Jordan Rudess, Mike Stern, Dean Brown, A R Rahman, Sivamani, Marco Minneman, Gary Willis, Dave Weckl, Tony Macalpine, Stu Hamm, Plini, Louiz Banks, Guthrie Govan, Ranjit Barot, Chad Wackerman, Chad Smith, Simon Phillips, Prasanna, Gergo Borlai, Victor Wooten, Federico Malaman, Darwin, Niladri Kumar, Stu Hamm, Sivamani, Bumblefoot, etc many more artists. Some Indian singers and directors that she has worked with are Salim Sulaiman, Clinton Cerejo, Neeti Mohan, Amit Trivedi, Benny Dayal, Sunidhi Chauhan, Shreya Ghoshal, Arijit Singh, Shalmali Kholgade, Sonu Kakkar, Shilpa Rao, Vishal-Shekar, Gurdasman, etc She has also been featured in magazines like Vogue, ForbesIndiaUnder30, NoTreble, RadarMusic, Bass Professor, Bass Magazine, BassQuaterly, Rollingstone, JazzInIndia, ParentCircle, RadioAndMusic, Platform, Femina, Hindu, NewIndianExpress, Verve and many other articles in newspapers like DNA, The Indian Express, Hindustan Times, Mid-Day, Mumbai Mirror, The Times of India, Bombay Times, etc.

She has played on Jimmy Fallon Show and Tiny Desk NPR and tours with Willow Smith.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: 2026 Employment Law Summit
description: Description California employers can expect a full slate of new employment laws in the New Year. Some of these changes require immediate action, such as policy revision and new notices, and all require an employer's full attention. Our presentation will cover these new laws, important changes at state and federal agencies, and other developments employers should watch in 2026. And as always, there will be plenty of time for questions, Some covered topics include:  \* Changes to the California Equal Pay Act and pay data reporting \* A dramatic new "Workplace Know Your Rights Act" notice to every employee \* State and local minimum wage increases \* New Paid Sick Leave, Victims' Leave and Paid Family Leave rules \* New collection authority for employee tips and gratuities \* Limits on employment contract terms and employee repayment requirements \* Expanded personnel file and employment training record requirements \* Increased public works pay data disclosure \* State efforts to regulate federally governed bargaining relationships \* Other agency and court developments affecting employers. Presenter: Richard C. Rybicki of Rybicki & Associates, P.C Rick is an attorney working closely with employers, helping them navigate a vast array of tough workplace issues. He offers a practical approach to developing employment policies and managing workplace conflicts.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

description:

Advance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,light, and challenging subjects to deepen technique and expression.

What you’ll do

This 8-week course is designed for artists ready to deepen their technical skills and personal expression in a calm, supportive, and solvent-free studio. It serves as the natural continuation of the Fall 2025 course “Palette & Possibility,” and is also open to experienced oil painters who wish to advance their practice within a framework focused on cognitive stimulation and emotional well-being. We will move beyond simple objects to tackle subjects that introduce new cognitive challenges, such as atmosphere, reflective surfaces, and simplified portrait elements. Emphasis remains on process over product, nurturing focus, spatial reasoning, and emotional insight. Through an explorative journey into composition, light, and “The Chromatic Voice”—your unique use of color— students will strengthen their artistic voices while continuing to reap the rewards of enhanced mental agility and profound emotional well-being.

Optional Materials Packet & Supply List

$35 includes all necessary paints, mediums, brushes, surfaces \(canvas panels\), and cleaning supplies for the 8 weeks. Students who wish to bring their own materials should view the supply list. You can view the full supply list here.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Beginning Gel Printing Workshop
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Magdalena Bogart
Monday, March 9th
1:00pm-4:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$45.00


Join us for an inspiring gel printing workshop with Magdalena Bogart, where you'll discover the
magic of this versatile and expressive art form. You will learn techniques for creating stunning,
layered prints using gel plates, rich textures, and vibrant colors.
If you have wanted to try out this fairly new and very popular way to make your own papers, whether you are an experienced artist or simply curious about the process, this workshop will provide plenty of creative inspiration and expert insights.

During the 3-hours workshop, you will learn the fundamentals of mono-printing with a gel plate,
including an in-depth look at the essential supplies needed. Magdalena will discuss different
types of plates and brayers, as well as the wide range of acrylic paints and inks. You will learn the basics of color theory to ensure great results for your projects.

You will get to try out many fun techniques on different papers. Magdalena will introduce various papers for gel printing, including white copy paper, calligraphy paper, deli paper, marker paper, and more each offering unique effects.

The workshop will also explore tools for making marks and textures, from found objects to store-bought supplies. Magdalena will demonstrate how to use stencils - both handmade and purchased, along with unconventional tools like silicone scrapers, scrapers, bubble wrap, buttons, yarn, and cardboard to create stunning patterns.

She will also cover techniques to embellish your prints incorporating acrylic pens, Inktense pencils and other techniques.
Additionally, Magdalena will provide expert guidance on cleaning, caring for, and storing gel plates to ensure their longevity. To wrap up the session, she will showcase creative ways to use your printed papers, including ideas for collages, handmade cards, and art journals, along with a take-home list of even more ways to incorporate your gel prints into future projects. Whether you are looking to refine your skills or try something new, this workshop promises to be an engaging and educational experience. Come explore the endless possibilities of gel printing.


To register for this workshop, please contact Magdalena at: 408.781.2589 or by email
at: mailto:mag.bogart@gmail.com mailto:mag.bogart@gmail.com mailto:mag.bogart@gmail.com mag.bogart@gmail.com mailto:mag.bogart@gmail.com mailto:mag.bogart@gmail.com

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

title: Become a Volunteer Seabird Monitor
description:
Join us to learn the skills you need to become a Volunteer Seabird Monitor with Stewards of the Coast and Redwoods.

No experience is necessary.

Stewards’ Seabird Monitoring program began in 2013, thanks to funding from the Bureau of Land Management. Stewards is partnering with the California Coastal National Monument \(CCNM\) to monitor breeding seabirds off the Sonoma Coast and is a local Chapter of the Seabird Protection Network.

Instructor: Hollis Bewley \(Seabird Monitoring Program Coordinator\)

This is a two-part training:

Part 1 of the training on zoom Monday March 9th from 6-7:30pm Seabird Monitoring Training part 1 Join Zoom Meeting: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/84074028922

Part 2 of the training on Thursday, March 19 from 9:30 AM to noon is an experiential training at a location meeting at the Bodega Head East parking lot. We’ll visit one or two of the monitoring sites, practice using the equipment and filling out data forms and sorting cormorant and becoming familiar with other bird species.

You can view a recording of last year’s training here: Seabird training part 1 2025 recording

This was an online introduction to the coastal bird species we will be monitoring and the use of data forms and other information.

What you’ll Create

Brand new to the town of Sonoma! Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! Swing is a fun social dance that is an instantly accessible way to enjoy social dancing to swing jazz, blues and rock and roll music. Swing is a form of social partner dance that evolved from Lindy Hop in the 1940s, and is based in six-count patterns that are simplified forms of Lindy Hop patterns. Enjoy a beautiful community of swing dancers and learn how to social dance. Absolutely no experience or partner needed. Simply show up, and I will provide the dance partner, as most students come alone/single. Just bring comfy shoes to dance in and your own water. Class is for singles and couples, alike! Everyone is welcome. We specialize in brand new dancers! Dance with confidence, build community, and learn something new in a friendly and kind environment! If you cannot make the entire series but still want to join a group class, please email or text Jasmine at \(510\) 388-5498 to inquire how to proceed/register.

**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger.
