title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: The Seasons - Dance on Ice
description:
Join us at Snoopy's Home Ice for an evening of art and athleticism of Dance on Ice.

Snoopy's Home Ice

March 13th 2026 at 7PM

Olympic Champion Gabriella Papadakis leads Ice Dance International's new tour, THE SEASONS—a celebration of artistry, athleticism, and speed that turns the rink into a living stage. Papadakis joins 2-time United States Champion Alissa Czisny and skating artist Rohene Ward in a company of ten world class skaters. From the opening movement they shape formations that move through four acts; each sharing a story that takes the audience on a journey.

THE SEASONS bursts with color, emotion, and momentum.  Ice Dance International company members launch daring lifts and jumps, crisp footwork, and seamless transitions that thrilled audiences on IDI's 2025 tour.

Papadakis, Czisny and Ward's presence elevates every phrase—their power, musical instinct, and magnetic connection ignite the audience and sharpen the edge of every moment. This is skating unbound: athletic, cinematic, and wildly alive.

Reaching 14 cities in early 2026, this is the rare chance to witness the possibilities of performance dance on ice. IDI's Artistic Director Douglas Webster says “THE SEASONS isn't just a show—it's a pulse, a spark, a reminder that when blades meet music and movement meets heart, the ice itself begins to sing.” 

Edge Class details: The edge class are meant to be community events that allow an opportunity to skate and warm up with the IDI company. Skills required are a solid ability of forwards and backwards skating/cross overs, all basic edges and turns through forward and backward 3s. Classes will develop past 3 turns into more advanced exercises. Both youth and adults are welcome. These classes are not learn to skate classes and advance at a rapid pace.

Meet and Greets follow the show and are a chance for VIP ticket holders to get autographs and photos with the IDI cast members. It generally take the cast 25 minutes to finish a show, regroup and get to the meet and greet! There will be flyers and markers for signing.

title: Indie After Dark
description:
Indie After Dark – Vallejo’s Night for Original Music

September 12 performers:

🔥 Agness Twin

San Francisco’s hypnotic post-punk / indie project led by Elisa Ovrahim. Gorgeous layered vocals, ringing guitars, cinematic folk shadows, and minimalist ethereal pop. Their new album Turn To Gold \(2024\) was mastered by John Golden \(Soundgarden, Melvins\) and has already carved its place on indie radio. Fresh from the Love & Rockets tour, Agness Twin’s live set will swallow you whole.

🔥 Pro-Pain!

Bay Area 4-piece that’s “HAVING A BLAST.” High-voltage energy, pure grit, and a sound built to light up the room. With their recent Bombs Away video, they’re proof that Vallejo’s underground scene is very much alive and screaming.

Every Second Friday, Indie After Dark brings the spotlight to independent music at the intimate and vibey 4th Corner Speakeasy in downtown Vallejo. Just steps from the heart of the Vallejo Art Walk, this monthly series invites you to discover bold new sounds in a setting made for connection—where the lights are low, the cocktails are strong, and the music runs deep.

Come early for the art, stay late for the music. It’s a night where Vallejo’s creative soul shines.

title: Safari West Presents! Wildlands Network
description: Conservation Dinner Series: Mari Galloway of  Wildlands Network joins us in the elephant room after dinner to give a talk about protecting local ecosystems, advancing Innovative Policy, transforming transportation networks, and building community. The conservation dinner series is complimentary to all dinner guests. If you want to attend this presentation, please call our reservations team at \(707\) 566-3667 or \(800\) 616-2695 and they can book it for you. Dinner starts at 7:00 PM.    Speaker Bio: As California Program Manager for Wildlands Network, Mari develops collaborative and strategic partnerships to further policy, road ecology, and land use initiatives that promote wildlife corridors and core habitat protections throughout the State of California. Mari spent her childhood on a farm in the San Joaquin Valley of California and her summers in the Sierra Nevada, near Ebbetts Pass. Her outdoor exposure inspired her to earn her bachelor's degree in environmental science from Humboldt State University. After college, she rode her bike across the U.S. and lived off the grid in Hawaii before taking a job coordinating settlements at a personal injury law firm in downtown San Francisco to gain exposure to the practice of law. In 2017, she attended the University of Oregon and obtained her law degree in 2020 and became licensed to practice law in both Oregon and California the following year. Mari lives in the San Joaquin Valley. When not strategizing a connected California, you'll find her with her dog, Bodie, either backpacking, trail running, cooking, practicing piano, brewing beer, gardening, or sketching.

description: Course Description: This course goes a step beyond basic CPR. description:
This class is perfect for bachata beginners that want to learn basic steps and skills, or those who want to refresh their foundational skills. We understand that learning something new can feel a little intimidating. That’s why our supportive and relaxed environment is specifically designed to make learning bachata basics an absolute blast!

Our friendly instructors will guide you through:

Basic directional steps: You’ll learn the fundamental movements that form the building blocks of all bachata dancing.

Proper frame for partner work: Discover how to connect comfortably and effectively with a partner, setting you up for smooth and enjoyable dances.

Simple turn patterns: We’ll introduce you to easy-to-follow turn patterns that will have you dancing with a partner in no time.

We’ve carefully organized our curriculum to ensure that each movement is easy to grasp and remember, building your confidence with every step. Our goal is to make learning fun. Join us to learn Bachata in Marin.

Important Details

No dance experience required: Whether you’ve never danced before or it’s been a while, you’re welcome here!

No partner necessary: Come solo or bring a friend—either way, you’ll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles: This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can’t wait to see you on the dance floor.

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits. 

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on first, second and fourth **Saturdays of the month from 9:45 - 10:15 AM at** ​**Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Marin, 240 Channing Way, San Rafael CA 94903**. Contact: Sue M. 415-298-6792​. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan. 

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

title: Aligning with Our Deepest Knowing: Wise View on the Path of Awakening
description:
with Dana DePalma, MA, MFT and Matthew Brensilver, PhD

The Buddha says that wise view is the starting point—it is also the culmination of awakening. Yet, delusion comes camouflaged as wisdom. What we do not yet understand shapes our view and obscures freedom. What are the processes by which we realize and align with our deepest knowing?

Together, we’ll consider the various aspects of the Dharma path that help us wake up to the assumptions that shape our experience and behavior: deep attention, spiritual friendship, and surrendering to this moment. We’ll reflect on what we’ve known in our clearest moments and what truly matters in how we relate to life. Together we’ll open to our embodied experience of wise view and how it supports meeting each moment with wisdom and love.

During this day of practice, we’ll offer guided and silent meditation practice, Dharma reflections, and time for dialogue. All are welcome.

title: Habitat Hikes: Chaparral
description:
Join CA Naturalist and Sugarloaf docent Marie Kay Hansen through the featured habitat: chaparral. Learn about the largest native plant community flora in California, characterized by rugged terrain and adaptive flora, during this 2-mile hike along Goodspeed Trail up to Pierson Rd, possibly until the unnamed creek crossing, and back. This hike is the first in our four-part "Habitats of Sugarloaf" hike series. Other hikes will explore the oak woodland, meadow and redwood forest habitats. 

Meet at the Goodspeed parking lot. Tickets are $10 for general admission, $5 for youth (12-17 year olds; all minors must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian), students, Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf or RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Wear layers, appropriate footwear for muddy and/or slippery trails, bring at least a quart of water, sun protection, and if desired, a snack, and binoculars. Heavy rain cancels. Parking fees apply.

$265 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $295 – Total Registration CostLearn photo transfer techniques onto canvas, wood, glass & paper in this hands-on workshop with Bay Area artist Margot Hartford. Create unique art pieces!

About the Class

Join Bay Area guest artist Margot Hartford, in this fun and creative one-day workshop where students will explore a unique photo transfer technique using personalized images. Learn how to effortlessly transfer photos onto various surfaces, including paper, canvas, glass and wood. Margot will demonstrate this process using a printable clear acetate, a specialized medium, and acrylic paint. Students will be introduced to the technique and will have the hands-on opportunity to create. The instructor will offer guided instruction in a supportive learning environment with a limited class size.

Workshop Requirements

After registration, in advance of the workshop, students will be required to email eight images to the instructor so they will be ready for use during the session. Each student will receive paper and wood panels to use as surfaces for transferring their images. The class materials fee will include all the tools needed to create the project. Students will be able to take home all of their images and finished projects at the end of the workshop.

Additional Notice

This class requires hand dexterity to maneuver tools, including X-Acto blades, and paintbrushes. The workshop includes six hours of instruction with a short 30 minute lunch break.All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Italian Ricotta Favorites: Sweet and Savory Classics
description:
Schedule

Saturday, March 14, 2026 10:00 AM – 12:00 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Bilingual, Culinary Arts

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$100 – Registration CostExplore ricotta three ways in this Italian cooking class. Make delicate gnudi, whipped ricotta crostini, and traditional torta di ricotta romana.

What you’ll do

Discover the incredible versatility of ricotta cheese in this hands-on Italian cooking class featuring three distinct preparations that showcase this beloved ingredient. You’ll learn techniques ranging from delicate pasta-making to elegant appetizers and classic Italian desserts. Start by creating pillowy ricotta gnudi, those cloud-like dumplings that are lighter than traditional gnocchi, served with a vibrant tomato sauce. Master the art of achieving the perfect texture and learn how to handle the delicate dough for consistently beautiful results. Next, prepare whipped ricotta crostini topped with honey and fresh thyme, an elegant appetizer that balances creamy, sweet, and herbaceous flavors on crispy bread. Finally, you’ll bake torta di ricotta romana, a traditional Roman ricotta cake that’s subtly sweet and wonderfully moist. This classic dessert demonstrates how ricotta creates tender, delicate baked goods with authentic Italian character. Throughout the class, you’ll gain confidence working with fresh ricotta, understanding how its moisture content and handling affect each dish differently. Whether you’re looking to expand your Italian cooking repertoire or simply love ricotta, this class provides techniques and recipes you’ll return to again and again. Perfect for intermediate home cooks ready to explore authentic Italian preparations.Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

description:
Enjoy your yoga experience in the beautiful setting of our park! Susan Topf’s Yoga Hike balances a mix of easy hiking and gentle yoga postures, breath work and guided meditation, no mat necessary. The route varies on weather conditions and group interest, typically covering 2-3 miles of varied terrain. All levels and ages welcome.

Tickets are $20.  Please wear weather appropriate clothing to feel comfortable being in a natural setting and bring water (as needed). Meet outside the Visitor Center unless otherwise noted in the reminder email prior to the hike. title: Salsa Beginner Marin – Saturday
description:
**Ready to learn intermediate steps and technique?** Join on on Saturday – Salsa Beginner Marin

Are you a beginner who’s always wanted to learn salsa? Salsa classes are designed to help you build a strong foundation. In this class, you’ll learn the fundamental footwork, practice the basic turns, and understand the essential body movement that will make you feel confident on the dance floor. This class is perfect for anyone ready to learn the techniques and foundational steps needed to start their salsa journey.

Salsa is fun, and we make learning it stress-free! Our relaxed, beginner-friendly class is the ideal starting point. You don’t need a partner, nor any dance experience!

In this class you will learn:

Basic directional steps that form the foundation of salsa.

Proper frame for comfortable and effective partner-work.

Simple, easy-to-remember turn patterns.

Get ready to learn the fundamentals and have a great time!

**Details:**

**No partner necessary**—rotations ensure everyone dances

Please wear **non-marking shoes** to protect the floor

Arrive 10 minutes early; warm up and settle in

**When:** Saturday, 10:00 am – 11:00 am

**Where:** 4140 Redwood Highway #8, San Rafael, CA

title: San Geronimo Repair Fair + Clothing Swap
description:
Do you have a lamp, small appliance, textile, or bike in need of repair?

Bring it to the Repair Fair!

Volunteers and specialized repair professionals will be on-hand to repair\* your items.  We ask that you stay with your item while it's being fixed, so you can learn tips for future maintenance, how to shop for repairable goods, and even how to repair things yourself!  

If you’d like to bring an item to repair, please register the item here: https://www.reusealliance.org/rf-reg \(Pre-registering allows us to prepare for your item!\)

This is a free public event.

This event will also include a Clothing Swap. Please bring clothing items and accessories \(clean and in good shape\) to share and bring home something new to you!

\*We cannot guarantee your item\(s\) will be repaired, depending on the existing damage or breakage, ability of volunteer fixers, and availability of materials for repair. Note we cannot work on microwaves and we can’t repair cell phones but we’re happy to refer you to local professionals who can. In addition, the textile department is not able to perform the following:

Replacing zippers

Repairing shoes, leather, or vinyl materials

Performing alterations \(making garments bigger/smaller\)

Replacing rivets/grommets

Hemming certain fabrics \(stretchy fabric, sleek/luxury fabrics e.g. prom dresses\)

If you are in need of garment hemming, we require that you please pin your garment to the desired length before you arrive.

Join Us!

Does fixing things sound like a fun way to spend a Saturday afternoon?  Or want to help out in other ways?  We need you!

Email volunteer@reusealliance.org or sign up here: https://volunteersignup.org/RMHLA

title: St. Patrick's Day 5K
description:
Proceeds benefiting Santa Rosa Recreation & Parks, the St. Patrick's Day 5K is an annual themed run/walk race open to all ages and abilities. The race is chip-timed and participants receive a commemorative finisher medal and mug. Stick around after the race for the post-run celebration complete with a beer or root beer, judged costume contest, fun activities, sponsor giveaways, and music!

Costume Contest

The judged costume will be held at 11:30 a.m. during the post-race celebration and everyone’s invited to participate, including race participants and all who attend to cheer the racers on! Winners, who are selected for each of the themed categories below, receive awesome prizes and plenty of o'plause! 

Most Spirited \(12 and under\) 

Most Convincing Leprechaun 

Best Wearing o’ the Green 

Best Dressed Team \(3\+ people\)

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. title: Vallejo Gardening Fair
description: The second annual Vallejo Gardening Fair brings together gardeners, families, local organizations, and businesses for a day of learning, sharing, and celebration. Designed for all experience levels, the fair highlights sustainable gardening practices, environmental stewardship, food growing, and outdoor wellness. Attendees can explore a variety of vendor tables offering free educational materials, resources, seeds, plants, tools, and other garden-related giveaways. Many vendors will also feature fun, hands-on activities and interactive items that make gardening accessible and engaging for all ages. Whether you're a seasoned gardener or just getting started, the Vallejo Gardening Fair is a welcoming space to discover local resources, connect with community experts, and leave inspired to grow-together.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Jazz & Ballet Combo: Ages 8-12
description:
Saturdays, January 17 – March 14, 2026 11:00 AM – 12:00 PM

Experience Level

Beginning

Event Categories: Dance & Movement, Kids

Ages

8 – 12 years old

$200 Total Registration Fee

Registration Fee includes full enrollment for 9 weeks of instruction and the recital costume fee

A fun and positive environment where kids can learn beginning ballet and basic jazz dance steps.

About the Class

A fun and positive environment where kids can learn beginning ballet and basic jazz dance steps. Instruction will include warm up exercises, increased vocabulary and beginning mini ballet barre ballet positions, across the floor exercises, beginning turns and leaps and beginning choreography is taught at the end of class to different styles of music. Exercises will be modified or enhanced to the individual’s level. Class will be conducted in a positive and attentive environment and is designed to develop memorization, flexibility, and musicality. This class will help the student gain coordination and confidence to take into their daily lives. Small performing opportunities based upon a child’s interest but is not mandatory. There will be a recital on Saturday, March 21. More details to follow. Benefits include listening skills and concentration, increased coordination, and an understanding of movement, i.e. time, space, directions and balance, social skills and development of creativity.

Required Supply List

Dance shoes, ballet slippers or barefoot \(Need shoes, see below\) Please no socks \(grippy kind ok\) or just tights as the floor can be slippery. Comfortable clothing to move in or dancewear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off of face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation.

Location

Room 213, Dance Studio

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

Focusing on recognizing and treating life-threatening situations in the critical minutes before 911 arrives, we will cover adult and infant CPR, AED use and handling choking, as well as what to do in cases of severe bleeding, sudden illness, heart attack, stroke and more.

title: Reclaim Your Calm A Harmonic Vagus Nerve Reset
description:
Reclaim Your Calm: Sound, Breath, & Flow

Join us for a unique somatic experience that uses the hypnotic, melodic resonance of the Rav Vast drum to bathe your nervous system in healing frequencies. Unlike traditional drumming, the Rav Vast creates a “sound forest” of overtones that helps the mind settle and the body soften. In this session, we integrate: Vibrational Sound Bath: The ethereal tones of the Rav Vast to lower your heart rate. Somatic Humming: To physically vibrate the vagus nerve from the inside out, syncing your breath with the drum. Flowing Qigong: Gentle, meditative movements to move “Qi” \(energy\) and release physical bracing in the body. Experience the shift from “survival mode” to “serenity.” Denise will guide you through: Qigong to open the body’s energy channels. Humming to stimulate your internal “calm” switch. A Rav Vast Sound Bath to wash away tension with beautiful, resonant harmonics. Come home to your body. Leave feeling grounded, peaceful, and renewed.

About Denise Aubin, MQT

Denise Aubin is a certified Medical Qigong Therapist \(MQT\) and the founder of Dance of Qigong. She discovered Qigong many years ago while traveling her own healing path and has a passion for assisting others on their healing journey back to love. Qigong is all about loving yourself and reconnecting with your joy. Denise loves teaching and empowering others in this ancient art form of self healing exercises. Denise received her degree from the International Institute of Medical Qigong and received certification as a Medical Qigong Therapist. Denise has been a teacher and healer for over thirty years.

title: Sea Chantey and Songs of the Sea Singalong
description: Please note the change of venue and time from our previous sing-alongs.\* Avast, ye saucy sailors! Come brave the perilous waters of Point Reyes and join us for a rollicking good time at Point Reyes National Seashore's Sea Chantey Sing-along at the Ken Patrick Visitor Center. Please bring your arsenal of sea chanteys, any musical instruments you'd like, and a willingness to laugh a lot!  It's so much fun when audience members lead shanties for the rest of us to join in on the chorus, and leading a song is encouraged! If you'd like to find a song \(or songs\) to share, I highly recommend setting one of your online music services to a sea chantey radio station and hear what's out there! Practice lyrics! Teach the chorus to our audience at the singalong! Our format is informal, mellow, and supportive, so if you've been wanting to push your comfort edge and lead a song, this is a perfect low-pressure opportunity. If you'd rather just singalong with the chantey choruses, that's fine too. We always have a great time no matter what. This free event is for chantey singers of all levels. Due to the nature of sea chanteys, there may be lyrics that are not appropriate for children. Reservations not required. To be added to the notification email list for future singalong dates, please email pore\_info@nps.gov For more information, please visit: nps.gov/pore/planyourvisit/calendar.htm

title: Catering to the Car: A Retro Road Trip Down Petaluma's Main Street
description:
Saturday, March 14, 4 - 5 pm at Petaluma Arts Center$15 PAC members, $20 non-members

Americana Reimagined at its best, this presentation will step into Petaluma's living history with historian Katherine Rinehart as she shares stories behind some of Petaluma's classic examples of roadside architecture. Discover how, through adaptive reuse, these properties reveal the economic and social trends that shaped the city's past while continuing to serve the needs of today.

Katherine J. Rinehart is a consulting historian specializing in house history documentation, archival organization, research, and exhibit development. She holds an MA in History from Sonoma State University and recently founded the Petaluma Signs Project,  dedicated to preserving historic signs that enrich our unique identity. Previously, Katherine managed the Sonoma County History & Genealogy Library. Her current clients include Sonoma State University Library and the Tomales Regional History Center. Katherine is an official Petaluma Good Egg, an annual honor celebrating individuals who advance the story of the city's unique past. She is the author of Petaluma: A History in Architecture and co-authored The Petaluma River: A Sketch Journal and Brief Historical Overview and the Petaluma Vintage Signs Guidebook.

LIVE! sets the stage on fire with the fury and passion of Spain's legendary Gypsies \(Roma\) with a Flamenco Dinner Show in the intimate atmosphere of THE BIG EASY. EXPERIENCE flamenco as stirring dances, blazing guitars, and soulful singing will transport you to another place and time. FEEL the HEAT...

FLAMENCO! LIVE!

Saturday, March 14th 2026

Melissa Cruz ~ Dancer BAOBOB Flamenco Dancers: Maria Soledad Sanchez, Kendra Pearson and Yumi Dews Pirouz "De Caspio" ~ Singer Roberto Aguilar ~ Guitarist

Showtime: 6 pm Doors: 5 pm $25 Pay at the Door Cash or Card

at The Big Easy Club and Restaurant 128 American Alley Petaluma USA

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* Flamenco Shows every other Month! The 2nd Saturday of the Month. Always different Artists. Always a different Show.

Flamenco Dinner Show with delicious food and a Full Bar are available, not included in entrance fee.

FLAMENCO! LIVE! ﻿was envisioned, conceived, and has thrived since 2002 in Sonoma County, California, now celebrating 24 years! Presenting the collaborative efforts of the Bay Area's finest Flamenco Singers, Guitarists and Dancers, and supporting local Flamenco students, dreamers, and talents, our goal has been to present top-notch performances. Phoebe Vernier "La Fibi" has brought decades of artistry and energy to the public of Sonoma County for the purpose of sharing the music, song and dance, the treasure of Southern Spain. Whether in the formal theater or in a casual setting, the respect, purity, and integrity of this traditional, yet living and evolving art form is always foremost.

Now in our 4rd Year of fiery Flamenco Shows!

title: Outback Presents Whitney Cummings: The Big Baby Tour
description:
Back to All Shows


Outback Presents 
Whitney Cummings: The Big Baby Tour

Saturday, March 14, 2026

7:00 pm


BUY TICKETS 


Whitney Cummings is a comedian, actor, writer, producer, director, and host of the hit podcast Good for You. Best known for creating and starring in the NBC series Whitney and co-creating the syndicated, Emmy-nominated CBS comedy 2 Broke Girls, she has become a leading voice in modern comedy. Cummings has released six stand-up specials, including Money Shot (2010), I Love You (2014), I’m Your Girlfriend (2016), Can I Touch It? (2019), Jokes (2022), and her latest, Mouthy, which debuted on OnlyFans in November 2023. She has also appeared in numerous television series and films, such as Good Mourning, Studio 666, How It Ends, and FOX’s Accused, further solidifying her presence on both the big and small screens. 
Beyond performing, Cummings is a successful author and filmmaker. In 2017, she published her memoir, I’m Fine… And Other Lies, and made her directorial debut with the feature adaptation of Louann Brizendine’s bestseller, The Female Brain. She continues to create, produce, and perform across platforms, bringing her sharp humor and fearless perspective to audiences worldwide. She currently lives in Los Angeles.

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: Marjorie Prime
description:
**Artificial Remembrance: The Intersection of Technology and Memory**

***“Jordan Harrison’s gently uncanny play imagines a future solution for a person in mourning: the recreation of someone you love as an artificial intelligence.”* —Kate Wyver, The Guardian**

**In *Marjorie Prime*, playwright Jordan Harrison delves into the intricate dance between human memory and artificial intelligence. Set in the not-so-distant future, the narrative centers on 85-year-old Marjorie, whose mind is gradually succumbing to dementia. To combat her fading recollections, her family introduces her to a “Prime”—a lifelike holographic projection of her late husband, Walter, programmed to retell the stories of their shared past. As Marjorie interacts with Walter Prime, the lines between authentic memories and reconstructed narratives blur, prompting profound questions about identity, the reliability of our recollections, and the extent to which technology can replicate the essence of human connection. This thought-provoking drama challenges audiences to consider what we choose to remember, what we wish to forget, and how the digital age reshapes the very fabric of our personal histories.**

***Marjorie Prime* has garnered critical acclaim for its insightful exploration and profound commentary on the human condition in an era where technology increasingly intertwines with our daily lives.**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: One hour, 20 mins including intermission

Thursdays Adult $33 Fri/Sat Eve Adult $39.95; Senior $36.95; Under 18 $26.95 Sat/Sun Matinee Adult $47.95; Senior $44.95 \*All prices include fees (707) 523-4185 **boxoffice@6thstreetplayhouse.com**

title: Charlie Hunter Trio
description: Charlie Hunter \(born May 23, 1967\) is an American guitarist, composer and bandleader.  First coming to prominence in the early '90s Hunter has since become one of the leading names in jazz, recording 17 albums. Hunter is noted for playing custom-made seven and eight-string guitars, on which he simultaneously plays basslines, rhythm guitar, and solos. Critic Sean Westergaard describes Hunter's innovative guitar technique as "mind-boggling ... he's an agile improviser with an ear for great tone, and always has excellent players alongside him in order to make great music, not to show off."

title: Safari West Presents! Native Bird Connections
description: Conservation Dinner Series: Jenny Papkra from  Native Bird Connections joins us in the elephant room after dinner to give a talk about birds. The conservation dinner series is complimentary to all dinner guests. If you want to attend this presentation, please call our reservations team at \(707\) 566-3667 or \(800\) 616-2695 and they can book it for you. Dinner starts at 7:00 PM.    About the Speaker: Jenny has a Bachelor's degree with honors from UC Davis in Environmental Interpretation. She has been involved with wildlife since 1988, first with Lindsay Museum for 13 years and now with Native Bird Connections for 22 years. Native Bird Connections is permitted with the State and the Federal Fish and Wildlife Departments to conduct educational programs within Northern California. NBC supports 13 non-releasable raptors as educational partners. Jenny maintains the NBC collection, delivers all of the programs and consults with organizations locally and beyond. She is an advisor for the Peregrine Team and the Kestrel Campaign in the Mt Diablo region Jenny has working experience with most California native wildlife and over 30 species of raptors. She received the William Penn Mott Jr. Environmental Award from the Orinda Association in 2009.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: Bay Team Mar 14-15 2026 USDAA Dog Agility
Historic Orchard Hike at Jack London State Historic Park
description:
Take a guided hike to the historic orchard, now part of Jack London State Historic Park, and learn about its remarkable restoration.  Along the way, keep an eye out for seasonal wildflowers and perhaps the first delicate blossoms on early blooming fruit trees.

Originally planted between 1908 and 1912, the orchard flourished in Jack London’s time before being abandoned for many years. Today, thanks to dedicated restoration efforts, it can once again be enjoyed by all who walk its trails.

The experience begins with an overview presented by Eric Metz, Director of Operations, who will share the history of the orchard and the challenges involved in its revival. From there, participants will hike through redwoods and mixed oak woodlands on a moderate, six-mile round-trip trek to the orchard.

 At the orchard, guests will tour the areas that have been thoughtfully revitalized and learn about unique obstacles overcome in restoring this landscape.

title: 2026 Seal Watch Volunteer Training
description: Do you love and want to connect people with the dynamic and beautiful Sonoma Coast? Do you care about the harbor seals at the mouth of the Russian River? Join us as a volunteer for Stewards Seal Watch Program. Volunteers support the safe viewing of harbor seals during weekends in the spring and summer months at Goat Rock State Beach near the mouth of the Russian River. Volunteers can join shifts at Goat Rock Beach, beach near the river mouth, and at an education table at the Jenner boat launch next to the visitor center. With your help, park visitors can learn about harbor seals and their pups, the natural history of the area, and how the Marine Mammal Protection Act ensures their safety.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Power of Letting Go: Cultivating Well-Being, Joy, and Freedom
description:
with James Baraz, MA

Spring is a natural time to reflect on what we are holding on to and what may be ready to be released. Just what does the phrase “let go” mean? Renunciation (*nekkhama* in Pāli), one of the ten perfections, is often misunderstood as sacrifice—something we should do because it’s “good for us.” In early Buddhist teachings, *nekkhama* is described not as deprivation, but as a letting go that supports genuine contentment and well-being, rooted in seeing more clearly what leads to suffering and what leads to freedom.

During this daylong program, which includes periods of guided silent sitting and walking meditation, participants will explore how habitual grasping—to thoughts, personal stories, possessions, roles, and a sense of control—shapes inner experience and contributes to stress. Drawing from contemplative teachings and incorporating perspectives from psychology on attachment and habitual mental patterns, our reflections and practices will focus on meeting these patterns with awareness and kindness, loosening unhelpful self-stories, softening the impulse to control, and cultivating generosity. This program is educational in nature and welcomes both new and experienced practitioners.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Breathless Sparkling Wines "Women’s History Celebration Sundays"
description:
**Breathless Sparkling Wines** is hosting a speaker and luncheon series which will be held **every Sunday in March** at the winery’s tranquil outdoor garden in Healdsburg to honor **Women’s History Month**. 

The **“Breathless Women’s History Celebration Sundays”** series aligns with the **National Women’s History Alliance**’s 2026 theme, “Leading the Change: Women Shaping a Sustainable Future,” which recognizes women advancing environmental, economic and social sustainability through leadership, innovation and community impact.

Each Breathless Wines Sparkling Garden Luncheon will be paired with a featured female speaker whose work reflects the evolving role of women in shaping industries and communities, sparkling wines, and wines paired with a lunch prepared by **Chef Beryl Adler** of Healdsburg's **Acorn Café.** Visit **BreathlessWines.com** for more.

title: In Her Power
description:
In Her Power

A Collaboration by Priscila Soares & JeanCherie

In Her Power is a group exhibition celebrating women’s presence, strength, and creative expression. Anchored by a collaborative, life-size sculptural work by Priscila Soares and JeanCherie, the exhibition brings together works by women artists exploring power as something lived, embodied, and deeply personal.

At the heart of the gallery stands a mountain lioness woman — a guardian figure shaped by two artists working together, each bringing her own voice, materials, and vision. Surrounding this central work, invited artists contribute pieces that reflect their own relationship to power, resilience, intuition, and selfhood.

Rather than offering a single definition, In Her Power invites viewers to witness many expressions of strength — quiet and fierce, ancestral and contemporary, individual and shared. It is both a celebration of women artists and an invitation to step into presence, creativity, and connection.

Opening Reception:

March 1, 12–4pm

Gallery Hours:

Sundays in March, 12–4pm

Location:

Mare Island Art Studios

110 Pintado St.

Vallejo, CA

title: Flora & Fauna - Watercolor Course with Hannah Day
description:
In this 4 week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium. The class will focus on strengthening one’s observational skills, giving the artist a foundation off of which to build their paintings in a step by step layering process, that trains the artist to see value and color

Our subject matter will be flora and fauna - a sampling of plants and animals. These subjects are great for beginners and experienced artists alike; their organic shapes make them forgiving drawing subjects, but their beauty can be a muse for life. 

This class will work both from photographs and from life, practicing observational drawing in addition to watercolor technique. With 4 class sessions, participants will have the opportunity to develop their skills and build muscle memory with a medium that often feels like it has a mind of its own. 

All materials provided.

Location: Bohemian Flowers Farm, 121 Bohemian Hwy, Freestone, CA

Dates: Four Sundays - March 8, 15, 22, 29

Time: 1 - 4 pm

Ages: Adults

Skill Levels: All Levels

title: Marjorie Prime
description:
**Artificial Remembrance: The Intersection of Technology and Memory**

***“Jordan Harrison’s gently uncanny play imagines a future solution for a person in mourning: the recreation of someone you love as an artificial intelligence.”* —Kate Wyver, The Guardian**

**In *Marjorie Prime*, playwright Jordan Harrison delves into the intricate dance between human memory and artificial intelligence. Set in the not-so-distant future, the narrative centers on 85-year-old Marjorie, whose mind is gradually succumbing to dementia. To combat her fading recollections, her family introduces her to a “Prime”—a lifelike holographic projection of her late husband, Walter, programmed to retell the stories of their shared past. As Marjorie interacts with Walter Prime, the lines between authentic memories and reconstructed narratives blur, prompting profound questions about identity, the reliability of our recollections, and the extent to which technology can replicate the essence of human connection. This thought-provoking drama challenges audiences to consider what we choose to remember, what we wish to forget, and how the digital age reshapes the very fabric of our personal histories.**

***Marjorie Prime* has garnered critical acclaim for its insightful exploration and profound commentary on the human condition in an era where technology increasingly intertwines with our daily lives.**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: One hour, 20 mins including intermission

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

description: This violin, French horn and piano trio has performed throughout the United States and the world since the late 90s. Rich in flavor, the trio brings to the stage a repertoire that adds depth to the violin, horn and piano through commissions and associations with other artists.  The ensemble was awarded grants for two residency programs in Turkey and was the resident chamber ensemble at the Pera College of Music in Istanbul.  To help expand the horn trio repertoire, past engagements have included commissioning composers Russell Steinberg and Tolga Ozdemir; recent commissions include new works by Andres Carrizo and Aida Shirazi, and Jan Bevan, poet and author. title: Live Nation Presents Ralph Barbosa: The Red 40 Tour
description:
Back to All Shows


Live Nation Presents 
Ralph Barbosa: The Red 40 Tour

Sunday, March 15, 2026

7:00 pm


BUY TICKETS
AGE RESTRICTION: 18 and above 
 


One of the shyest attention hogs ever to do comedy, Ralph Barbosa’s disarming and laid-back style has made him a stand-out on stage, on TV, and as host of the Formula Bean YouTube channel with Luis Cisneros. Last summer, Barbosa premiered his second hour-long stand-up special, Ralph Barbosa: Planet Bosa, as part of Hulu’s new Hularious comedy brand. 
His first hour-long stand-up special, Ralph Barbosa: Cowabunga, premiered on Netflix on October 31, 2023, and ranked as the #3 TV show on Netflix throughout its first week on the service. 
In July 2024, Barbosa was selected as one of Variety’s 10 Comics to Watch for 2024 and toured theaters throughout North America, including two sold-out theater shows as part of the Netflix Is A Joke Fest 2024, as well as hosting the kick-off show. 2023 was Barbosa’s break-out year, during which he was a guest on The Joe Rogan Experience, made his debut on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, and performed Comedy Central Stand-up Featuring: Ralph Barbosa, which topped 6 million views on YouTube. 
Barbosa also starred in the HBO Max comedy special, Entre Nos: The Winners 3 in 2022, and earlier that year his Don’t Tell Comedy performance was released on YouTube and now has over 6 million views. 


This event will be a phone-free experience. Use of phones, smart watches, and accessories will not be permitted in the performance space. Upon arrival at the venue, all phones, smart watches, and accessories will be secured in individual Yondr pouches that will be opened at the end of the event. Guests maintain possession of their devices at all times, and can access them throughout the event only in designated Phone Use Areas within the venue. All devices will be re-secured in Yondr pouches before returning to the performance space. Anyone seen using a device (phone, smart watch or accessories) during the performance will be escorted out of the venue. More info here. 



THIRD PARTY RESELLERS
Don’t get taken by deceptive online resellers who use bots to buy tickets and then mark up their prices. The only safe way to protect your purchase and guarantee the best seats at the lowest cost is to work directly with us: through our website, by phone, or at our box office in Santa Rosa. Plus, we’re not bots. Our friendly team members are easily accessible by phone or at the box office to provide customer support.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: Watercolor Fundamentals Part 1
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesdays
10:30AM-1:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$270.00


*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*

There will be a materials fee of $15 plus tax for the series.


Watercolor Fundamentals - Part 1

This class focuses on the simple delight of mixing color with water, brushing it on paper, and watching what happens as it moves and dries. You will learn easy ways to create paintings that are all about color and the sometimes unpredictable nature of water.

No drawing skills are needed.

In this class we will explore the basic principles of watercolor painting. Learn or refresh your understanding of brush handling, brush care and setting up, the benefits of “good paper”, watercolor lights and darks, flat and graded washes, wet-on-wet techniques such as charging, wet-on-dry techniques such as glazing, color wheel, color theory, color mixing, and more. Simple applications of these techniques invite you to experiment and play.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

*Brushes, palettes, set-ups, and paint will be provided.*


To see Anne's work and to learn more about this class, please visit her website at: http://www.miraaster.com https://www.miraaster.com/ www.miraaster.com


To register for this workshop, please contact Anne by email at: classes@miraaster.com mailto:classes@miraaster.com mailto:amillett@gmail.com

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM – 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 – Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you’ll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist:  Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\), Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\) . Inspired by their playful styles, students will design and develop their very own characters—deciding where these characters live, work, play, eat, and sleep! Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.  Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

 watercolor, paint, pens, and collage

 recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use watercolor techniques to add color and mood

How scale helps characters and environments feel real

The arc of a story—beginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 116

title: After-School Adventure Gaming
description:
Tuesdays, February 10 – April 7, 2026 4:00 PM – 6:00 PM Exception: No class March 24

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Teens

Age\(s\)

10-15

$360 – Registration CostPresented by the Sonoma Community Center in partnership with The Game Academy

Join Adventure Gaming classes with The Game Academy! Play D&D, build community, and grow empathy through weekly storytelling sessions.

About the class

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for 2-hour sessions over an 8-week term. Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and tactical challenges to be overcome… all based on the players’ interests. This uniquely tailored experience provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. We hope your child will join us for a new adventure this coming Fall Term at the Sonoma Community Center.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Room 211, Conference Room
